main.name: S47

content.p: To provide for the management of the natural resources of the United States, and for other purposes.

main.enactingFormula: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,

subsection.heading: Short title.—
subsection.content: This Act may be cited as the “John D. Dingell, Jr. Conservation, Management, and Recreation Act”.

subsection.heading: Table of contents.—
subsection.content: The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

section.heading: Definition of Secretary
section.content: In this Act, the term “Secretary” means the Secretary of the Interior.

subsection.heading: Purposes.—
subsection.chapeau: The purposes of this section are—

paragraph.content: to authorize, direct, expedite and facilitate the land exchange set forth herein; and

to promote enhanced public outdoor recreational and natural resource conservation opportunities in the Pike National Forest near Pikes Peak, Colorado, via acquisition of the non-Federal land and trail easement.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: BHI.—
paragraph.content: The term “BHI” means Broadmoor Hotel, Inc., a Colorado corporation.

paragraph.heading: Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “Federal land” means all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to approximately 83 acres of land within the Pike National Forest, El Paso County, Colorado, together with a nonexclusive perpetual access easement to BHI to and from such land on Forest Service Road 371, as generally depicted on the map entitled “Proposed Crags Land Exchange–Federal Parcel–Emerald Valley Ranch” and dated March 2015.

paragraph.heading: Non-Federal land.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “non-Federal land” means the land and trail easement to be conveyed to the Secretary by BHI in the exchange and is—

subparagraph.content: approximately 320 acres of land within the Pike National Forest, Teller County, Colorado, as generally depicted on the map entitled “Proposed Crags Land Exchange–Non-Federal Parcel–Crags Property” and dated March 2015; and

a permanent trail easement for the Barr Trail in El Paso County, Colorado, as generally depicted on the map entitled “Proposed Crags Land Exchange–Barr Trail Easement to United States” and dated March 2015, and which shall be considered as a voluntary donation to the United States by BHI for all purposes of law.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture, unless otherwise specified.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: If BHI offers to convey to the Secretary all right, title, and interest of BHI in and to the non-Federal land, the Secretary shall accept the offer and simultaneously convey to BHI the Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Land title.—
paragraph.content: Title to the non-Federal land conveyed and donated to the Secretary under this section shall be acceptable to the Secretary and shall conform to the title approval standards of the Attorney General of the United States applicable to land acquisitions by the Federal Government.

paragraph.heading: Perpetual access easement to BHI.—
paragraph.chapeau: The nonexclusive perpetual access easement to be granted to BHI as shown on the map referred to in subsection (b)(2) shall allow—

subparagraph.content: BHI to fully maintain, at BHI’s expense, and use Forest Service Road 371 from its junction with Forest Service Road 368 in accordance with historic use and maintenance patterns by BHI; and

full and continued public and administrative access and use of Forest Service Road 371 in accordance with the existing Forest Service travel management plan, or as such plan may be revised by the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: Route and condition of road.—
paragraph.content: BHI and the Secretary may mutually agree to improve, relocate, reconstruct, or otherwise alter the route and condition of all or portions of such road as the Secretary, in close consultation with BHI, may determine advisable.

paragraph.heading: Exchange costs.—
paragraph.content: BHI shall pay for all land survey, appraisal, and other costs to the Secretary as may be necessary to process and consummate the exchange directed by this section, including reimbursement to the Secretary, if the Secretary so requests, for staff time spent in such processing and consummation.

paragraph.heading: Appraisals.—
paragraph.chapeau: The values of the lands to be exchanged under this section shall be determined by the Secretary through appraisals performed—

subparagraph.chapeau: in accordance with—

clause.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions;
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice; and
appraisal instructions issued by the Secretary; and

subparagraph.content: by an appraiser mutually agreed to by the Secretary and BHI.

paragraph.heading: Equal value exchange.—
paragraph.chapeau: The values of the Federal land and non-Federal land parcels exchanged shall be equal, or if they are not equal, shall be equalized as follows:

subparagraph.heading: Surplus of Federal land value.—
subparagraph.content: If the final appraised value of the Federal land exceeds the final appraised value of the non-Federal land parcel identified in subsection (b)(3)(A), BHI shall make a cash equalization payment to the United States as necessary to achieve equal value, including, if necessary, an amount in excess of that authorized pursuant to section 206(b) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of l976 (43 U.S.C. 1716(b)).

subparagraph.heading: Use of funds.—
subparagraph.chapeau: Any cash equalization moneys received by the Secretary under subparagraph (A) shall be—

clause.content: deposited in the fund established under Public Law 90–171 (commonly known as the “Sisk Act”; 16 U.S.C. 484a); and
made available to the Secretary for the acquisition of land or interests in land in Region 2 of the Forest Service.

subparagraph.heading: Surplus of non-Federal land value.—
subparagraph.content: If the final appraised value of the non-Federal land parcel identified in subsection (b)(3)(A) exceeds the final appraised value of the Federal land, the United States shall not make a cash equalization payment to BHI, and surplus value of the non-Federal land shall be considered a donation by BHI to the United States for all purposes of law.

subparagraph.heading: Special Use Permit.—
subparagraph.content: The appraised value of the Federal land parcel shall not reflect any increase or diminution in value due to the special use permit existing on the date of enactment of this Act to BHI on the parcel and improvements thereunder.

subparagraph.heading: Barr Trail easement.—
subparagraph.content: The Barr Trail easement donation identified in subsection (b)(3)(B) shall not be appraised for purposes of this section.

subparagraph.heading: Withdrawal.—
subparagraph.content: Lands acquired by the Secretary under this section shall, without further action by the Secretary, be permanently withdrawn from all forms of appropriation and disposal under the public land laws (including the mining and mineral leasing laws) and the Geothermal Steam Act of 1930 (30 U.S.C. 1001 et seq.).

subparagraph.heading: Withdrawal revocation.—
subparagraph.content: Any public land order that withdraws the Federal land from appropriation or disposal under a public land law shall be revoked to the extent necessary to permit disposal of the Federal land parcel to BHI.

subparagraph.heading: Withdrawal of Federal land.—
subparagraph.content: All Federal land authorized to be exchanged under this section, if not already withdrawn or segregated from appropriation or disposal under the public lands laws upon enactment of this Act, is hereby so withdrawn, subject to valid existing rights, until the date of conveyance of the Federal land to BHI.

paragraph.heading: Postexchange land management.—
paragraph.content: Land acquired by the Secretary under this section shall become part of the Pike-San Isabel National Forest and be managed in accordance with the laws, rules, and regulations applicable to the National Forest System.

paragraph.heading: Exchange timetable.—
paragraph.content: It is the intent of Congress that the land exchange directed by this section be consummated no later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act.

subparagraph.heading: Minor errors.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary and BHI may by mutual agreement make minor boundary adjustments to the Federal and non-Federal lands involved in the exchange, and may correct any minor errors in any map, acreage estimate, or description of any land to be exchanged.

subparagraph.heading: Conflict.—
subparagraph.content: If there is a conflict between a map, an acreage estimate, or a description of land under this section, the map shall control unless the Secretary and BHI mutually agree otherwise.

subparagraph.heading: Availability.—
subparagraph.content: Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall file and make available for public inspection in the headquarters of the Pike-San Isabel National Forest a copy of all maps referred to in this section.

subsection.heading: In general.—
subsection.content: The boundary of the Arapaho National Forest in the State of Colorado is adjusted to incorporate the approximately 92.95 acres of land generally depicted as “The Wedge” on the map entitled “Arapaho National Forest Boundary Adjustment” and dated November 6, 2013, and described as lots three, four, eight, and nine of section 13, Township 4 North, Range 76 West, Sixth Principal Meridian, Colorado. A lot described in this subsection may be included in the boundary adjustment only after the Secretary of Agriculture obtains written permission for such action from the lot owner or owners.

subsection.heading: Bowen Gulch Protection Area.—
subsection.content: The Secretary of Agriculture shall include all Federal land within the boundary described in subsection (a) in the Bowen Gulch Protection Area established under section 6 of the Colorado Wilderness Act of 1993 (16 U.S.C. 539j).

subsection.heading: Land and Water Conservation Fund.—
subsection.content: For purposes of section 200306(a)(2)(B)(i) of title 54, United States Code, the boundaries of the Arapaho National Forest, as modified under subsection (a), shall be considered to be the boundaries of the Arapaho National Forest as in existence on January 1, 1965.

subsection.heading: Public motorized use.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section opens privately owned lands within the boundary described in subsection (a) to public motorized use.

subsection.heading: Access to non-Federal lands.—
subsection.content: Notwithstanding the provisions of section 6(f) of the Colorado Wilderness Act of 1993 (16 U.S.C. 539j(f)) regarding motorized travel, the owners of any non-Federal lands within the boundary described in subsection (a) who historically have accessed their lands through lands now or hereafter owned by the United States within the boundary described in subsection (a) shall have the continued right of motorized access to their lands across the existing roadway.

section.heading: Santa Ana River Wash Plan land exchange

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Conservation District.—
paragraph.content: The term “Conservation District” means the San Bernardino Valley Water Conservation District, a political subdivision of the State of California.

paragraph.heading: Federal exchange parcel.—
paragraph.content: The term “Federal exchange parcel” means the approximately 90 acres of Federal land administered by the Bureau of Land Management generally depicted as “BLM Equalization Land to SBVWCD” on the Map and is to be conveyed to the Conservation District if necessary to equalize the fair market values of the lands otherwise to be exchanged.

paragraph.heading: Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “Federal land” means the approximately 327 acres of Federal land administered by the Bureau of Land Management generally depicted as “BLM Land to SBVWCD” on the Map.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “Map” means the map entitled “Santa Ana River Wash Land Exchange” and dated September 3, 2015.

paragraph.heading: Non-Federal exchange parcel.—
paragraph.content: The term “non-Federal exchange parcel” means the approximately 59 acres of land owned by the Conservation District generally depicted as “SBVWCD Equalization Land” on the Map and is to be conveyed to the United States if necessary to equalize the fair market values of the lands otherwise to be exchanged.

paragraph.heading: Non-Federal Land.—
paragraph.content: The term “non-Federal Land” means the approximately 310 acres of land owned by the Conservation District generally depicted as “SBVWCD to BLM” on the Map.

subsection.heading: Exchange of land; equalization of value.—

paragraph.heading: Exchange authorized.—
paragraph.chapeau: Notwithstanding the land use planning requirements of sections 202, 210, and 211 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1712, 1720, 1721), subject to valid existing rights, and conditioned upon any equalization payment necessary under section 206(b) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1716(b)), and paragraph (2), as soon as practicable, but not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, if the Conservation District offers to convey the exchange land to the United States, the Secretary shall—

subparagraph.content: convey to the Conservation District all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the Federal land, and any such portion of the Federal exchange parcel as may be required to equalize the values of the lands exchanged; and

accept from the Conservation District a conveyance of all right, title, and interest of the Conservation District in and to the non-Federal land, and any such portion of the non-Federal exchange parcel as may be required to equalize the values of the lands exchanged.

paragraph.heading: Equalization payment.—
paragraph.chapeau: To the extent an equalization payment is necessary under section 206(b) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1716(b)), the amount of such equalization payment shall first be made by way of in-kind transfer of such portion of the Federal exchange parcel to the Conservation District, or transfer of such portion of the non-Federal exchange parcel to the United States, as the case may be, as may be necessary to equalize the fair market values of the exchanged properties. The fair market value of the Federal exchange parcel or non-Federal exchange parcel, as the case may be, shall be credited against any required equalization payment. To the extent such credit is not sufficient to offset the entire amount of equalization payment so indicated, any remaining amount of equalization payment shall be treated as follows:

subparagraph.content: If the equalization payment is to equalize values by which the Federal land exceeds the non-Federal land and the credited value of the non-Federal exchange parcel, Conservation District may make the equalization payment to the United States, notwithstanding any limitation regarding the amount of the equalization payment under section 206(b) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1716(b)). In the event Conservation District opts not to make the indicated equalization payment, the exchange shall not proceed.

If the equalization payment is to equalize values by which the non-Federal land exceeds the Federal land and the credited value of the Federal exchange parcel, the Secretary shall order the exchange without requirement of any additional equalization payment by the United States to the Conservation District.
The value of the land to be exchanged under this section shall be determined by appraisals conducted by one or more independent and qualified appraisers.

The appraisals shall be conducted in accordance with nationally recognized appraisal standards, including, as appropriate, the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions and the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

paragraph.heading: Title approval.—
paragraph.content: Title to the land to be exchanged under this section shall be in a format acceptable to the Secretary and the Conservation District.

paragraph.heading: Map and legal descriptions.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall finalize a map and legal descriptions of all land to be conveyed under this section. The Secretary may correct any minor errors in the map or in the legal descriptions. The map and legal descriptions shall be on file and available for public inspection in appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management.

paragraph.heading: Costs of conveyance.—
paragraph.content: As a condition of conveyance, any costs related to the conveyance under this section shall be paid by the Conservation District.

subparagraph.content: The Act of February 20, 1909 (35 Stat. 641), shall not apply to the Federal land and any public exchange land transferred under this section.

The exchange of lands under this section shall be subject to continuing rights of the Conservation District under the Act of February 20, 1909 (35 Stat. 641), on the non-Federal land and any exchanged portion of the non-Federal exchange parcel for the continued use, maintenance, operation, construction, or relocation of, or expansion of, groundwater recharge facilities on the non-Federal land, to accommodate groundwater recharge of the Bunker Hill Basin to the extent that such activities are not in conflict with any Habitat Conservation Plan or Habitat Management Plan under which such non-Federal land or non-Federal exchange parcel may be held or managed.

paragraph.heading: FLPMA.—
paragraph.content: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.), shall apply to the exchange of land under this section.

subsection.heading: Cancellation of Secretarial Order 241.—
subsection.content: Secretarial Order 241, dated November 11, 1929 (withdrawing a portion of the Federal land for an unconstructed transmission line), is terminated and the withdrawal thereby effected is revoked.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: City.—
paragraph.content: The term “City” means the city of Tucson, Arizona.

paragraph.heading: Non-Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “non-Federal land” means the approximately 172.8-acre parcel of City land identified in the patent numbered 02–90–0001 and dated October 4, 1989, and more particularly described as lots 3 and 4, S1/2NW1/4, sec. 5, T.14 S., R.15 E., Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona.

subsection.heading: Conveyance of Federal reversionary interest in land located in Tucson, Arizona.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Secretary shall convey to the City, without consideration, the reversionary interests of the United States in and to the non-Federal land for the purpose of unencumbering the title to the non-Federal land to enable economic development of the non-Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Legal descriptions.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the exact legal descriptions of the non-Federal land shall be determined in a manner satisfactory to the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: Additional terms and conditions.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary may require such additional terms and conditions to the conveyance under paragraph (1), consistent with that paragraph, as the Secretary considers appropriate to protect the interests of the United States.

paragraph.heading: Costs.—
paragraph.content: The City shall pay all costs associated with the conveyance under paragraph (1), consistent with that paragraph, including the costs of any surveys, recording costs, and other reasonable costs.

subsection.heading: In general.—
subsection.content: Subject to valid existing rights, the State of Utah may select any lands in T. 6 S. and T. 7 S., R. 1 W., Salt Lake Base and Meridian, that are owned by the United States, under the administrative jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management, and identified as available for disposal by land exchange in the Record of Decision for the Pony Express Resource Management Plan and Rangeland Program Summary for Utah County (January 1990), as amended by the Pony Express Plan Amendment (November 1997), in fulfillment of the land grants made in sections 6, 8, and 12 of the Act of July 16, 1894 (28 Stat. 107) as generally depicted on the map entitled “Proposed Utah County Quantity Grants” and dated June 27, 2017, to further the purposes of the State of Utah School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration, without further land use planning action by the Bureau of Land Management.

subsection.heading: Application.—
subsection.content: The criteria listed in Decision 3 of the Lands Program of the resource management plan described in subsection (a) shall not apply to any land selected under that subsection.

subsection.heading: Effect on limitation.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section affects the limitation established under section 2815(d) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000 (Public Law 106–65).

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: County.—
paragraph.content: The term “County” means Custer County, South Dakota.

paragraph.heading: Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “Federal land” means all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to approximately 65.7 acres of National Forest System land, as generally depicted on the map.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “map” means the map entitled “Custer County Airport Conveyance” and dated October 19, 2017.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Subject to the terms and conditions described in paragraph (2), if the County submits to the Secretary an offer to acquire the Federal land for the market value, as determined by the appraisal under paragraph (3), the Secretary shall convey the Federal land to the County.

paragraph.heading: Terms and conditions.—
paragraph.chapeau: The conveyance under paragraph (1) shall be—

subparagraph.content: subject to valid existing rights;
made by quitclaim deed; and
subject to any other terms and conditions as the Secretary considers appropriate to protect the interests of the United States.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall complete an appraisal to determine the market value of the Federal land.

subparagraph.heading: Standards.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The appraisal under subparagraph (A) shall be conducted in accordance with—

clause.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions; and
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

subparagraph.heading: Availability of map.—
subparagraph.content: The map shall be kept on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate office of the Forest Service.

subparagraph.heading: Correction of errors.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary may correct any errors in the map.

paragraph.heading: Consideration.—
paragraph.content: As consideration for the conveyance under paragraph (1), the County shall pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the market value of the Federal land, as determined by the appraisal under paragraph (3).

paragraph.heading: Survey.—
paragraph.content: The exact acreage and legal description of the Federal land to be conveyed under paragraph (1) shall be determined by a survey satisfactory to the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: Costs of conveyance.—
paragraph.chapeau: As a condition on the conveyance under paragraph (1), the County shall pay to the Secretary all costs associated with the conveyance, including the cost of—

subparagraph.content: the appraisal under paragraph (3); and
the survey under paragraph (6).

paragraph.heading: Proceeds from the sale of land.—
paragraph.chapeau: Any proceeds received by the Secretary from the conveyance under paragraph (1) shall be—

subparagraph.content: deposited in the fund established under Public Law 90–171 (commonly known as the “Sisk Act”) (16 U.S.C. 484a); and
available to the Secretary until expended, without further appropriation, for the acquisition of inholdings in units of the National Forest System in the State of South Dakota.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: District.—
paragraph.content: The term “District” means the Tucson Unified School District No. 1, a school district recognized as such under the laws of the State of Arizona.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “Map” means the map entitled ‘“Pascua Yaqui Tribe Land Conveyance Act”, dated March 14, 2016, and on file and available for public inspection in the local office of the Bureau of Land Management.

paragraph.heading: Recreation and Public Purposes Act.—
paragraph.content: The term “Recreation and Public Purposes Act” means the Act of June 14, 1926 (43 U.S.C. 869 et seq.).

paragraph.heading: Tribe.—
paragraph.content: The term “Tribe” means the Pascua Yaqui Tribe of Arizona, a federally recognized Indian Tribe.

subsection.heading: Land to be held in trust.—

paragraph.heading: Parcel A.—
paragraph.content: Subject to paragraph (2) and to valid existing rights, all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the approximately 39.65 acres of Federal lands generally depicted on the map as “Parcel A” are declared to be held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the Tribe.

paragraph.heading: Effective date.—
paragraph.content: Paragraph (1) shall take effect on the day after the date on which the District relinquishes all right, title, and interest of the District in and to the approximately 39.65 acres of land described in paragraph (1).

subsection.heading: Lands to be conveyed to the district.—

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Subject to valid existing rights and payment to the United States of the fair market value, the United States shall convey to the District all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the approximately 13.24 acres of Federal lands generally depicted on the map as “Parcel B”.

subparagraph.heading: Determination of fair market value.—
subparagraph.content: The fair market value of the property to be conveyed under subparagraph (A) shall be determined by the Secretary in accordance with the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions and the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

subparagraph.heading: Costs of conveyance.—
subparagraph.content: As a condition of the conveyance under this paragraph, all costs associated with the conveyance shall be paid by the District.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: If, not later than 1 year after the completion of the appraisal required by subparagraph (C), the District submits to the Secretary an offer to acquire the Federal reversionary interest in all of the approximately 27.5 acres of land conveyed to the District under Recreation and Public Purposes Act and generally depicted on the map as “Parcel C”, the Secretary shall convey to the District such reversionary interest in the lands covered by the offer. The Secretary shall complete the conveyance not later than 30 days after the date of the offer.

subparagraph.heading: Survey.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall complete a survey of the lands described in this paragraph to determine the precise boundaries and acreage of the lands subject to the Federal reversionary interest.

subparagraph.heading: Appraisal.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall complete an appraisal of the Federal reversionary interest in the lands identified by the survey required by subparagraph (B). The appraisal shall be completed in accordance with the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions and the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

subparagraph.heading: Consideration.—
subparagraph.content: As consideration for the conveyance of the Federal reversionary interest under this paragraph, the District shall pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the appraised value of the Federal interest, as determined under subparagraph (C). The consideration shall be paid not later than 30 days after the date of the conveyance.

subparagraph.heading: Costs of conveyance.—
subparagraph.content: As a condition of the conveyance under this paragraph, all costs associated with the conveyance, including the cost of the survey required by subparagraph (B) and the appraisal required by subparagraph (C), shall be paid by the District.

subsection.heading: Gaming prohibition.—
subsection.content: The Tribe may not conduct gaming activities on lands taken into trust pursuant to this section, either as a matter of claimed inherent authority, under the authority of any Federal law, including the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2701 et seq.), or under regulations promulgated by the Secretary or the National Indian Gaming Commission.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: There shall be no Federal reserved right to surface water or groundwater for any land taken into trust by the United States for the benefit of the Tribe under this section.

paragraph.heading: State water rights.—
paragraph.content: The Tribe retains any right or claim to water under State law for any land taken into trust by the United States for the benefit of the Tribe under this section.

paragraph.heading: Forfeiture or abandonment.—
paragraph.content: Any water rights that are appurtenant to land taken into trust by the United States for the benefit of the Tribe under this section may not be forfeited or abandoned.

paragraph.heading: Administration.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section affects or modifies any right of the Tribe or any obligation of the United States under Public Law 95–375.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: County.—
paragraph.content: The term “County” means La Paz County, Arizona.

paragraph.heading: Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “Federal land” means the approximately 5,935 acres of land managed by the Bureau of Land Management and designated as “Federal land to be conveyed” on the map.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “map” means the map prepared by the Bureau of Land Management entitled “Proposed La Paz County Land Conveyance” and dated October 1, 2018.

subsection.heading: Conveyance to La Paz County, Arizona.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding the planning requirement of sections 202 and 203 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1712, 1713) and in accordance with this section and other applicable law, as soon as practicable after receiving a request from the County to convey the Federal land, the Secretary shall convey the Federal land to the County.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The conveyance under paragraph (1) shall be subject to—

clause.content: valid existing rights; and
such terms and conditions as the Secretary determines to be necessary.

subparagraph.heading: Exclusion.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary shall exclude from the conveyance under paragraph (1) any Federal land that contains significant cultural, environmental, wildlife, or recreational resources.

paragraph.heading: Payment of fair market value.—
paragraph.chapeau: The conveyance under paragraph (1) shall be for the fair market value of the Federal land to be conveyed, as determined—

subparagraph.content: in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.); and

subparagraph.chapeau: based on an appraisal that is conducted in accordance with—

clause.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions; and
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

paragraph.heading: Protection of Tribal cultural artifacts.—
paragraph.chapeau: As a condition of the conveyance under paragraph (1), the County shall, and as a condition of any subsequent conveyance, any subsequent owner shall—

subparagraph.content: make good faith efforts to avoid disturbing Tribal artifacts;
minimize impacts on Tribal artifacts if they are disturbed;
coordinate with the Colorado River Indian Tribes Tribal Historic Preservation Office to identify artifacts of cultural and historic significance; and
allow Tribal representatives to rebury unearthed artifacts at or near where they were discovered.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The map shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management.

subparagraph.heading: Corrections.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary and the County may, by mutual agreement—

clause.content: make minor boundary adjustments to the Federal land to be conveyed under paragraph (1); and
correct any minor errors in the map, an acreage estimate, or the description of the Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Withdrawal.—
paragraph.content: The Federal land is withdrawn from the operation of the mining and mineral leasing laws of the United States.

paragraph.heading: Costs.—
paragraph.chapeau: As a condition of the conveyance of the Federal land under paragraph (1), the County shall pay—

subparagraph.content: an amount equal to the appraised value determined in accordance with paragraph (3)(B); and
all costs related to the conveyance, including all surveys, appraisals, and other administrative costs associated with the conveyance of the Federal land to the County under paragraph (1).

paragraph.heading: Proceeds from the sale of land.—
paragraph.chapeau: The proceeds from the sale of land under this subsection shall be—

subparagraph.content: deposited in the Federal Land Disposal Account established by section 206(a) of the Federal Land Transaction Facilitation Act (43 U.S.C. 2305(a)); and
used in accordance with that Act (43 U.S.C. 2301 et seq.).

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Claimant.—
paragraph.content: The term “claimant” means any individual, group, or corporation authorized to hold title to land or mineral interests in land in the State of Louisiana with a valid claim to the omitted land, including any mineral interests.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “Map” means the map entitled “Lands as Delineated by Original Survey December 18, 1842 showing the 1969 Meander Line at the 148.6 Elevation Line” and dated January 30, 2018.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The term “omitted land” means the land in lots 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, and 13 of sec. 30, T. 16 N., R. 10 W., Louisiana Meridian, comprising a total of approximately 229.72 acres, as depicted on the Map, that—

clause.content: was in place during the Original Survey; but
was not included in the Original Survey.

subparagraph.heading: Inclusion.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The term “omitted land” includes—

clause.content: Peggy's Island in lot 1 of sec. 17, T. 16 N., R. 10 W., Louisiana Meridian; and
Hog Island in lot 1 of sec. 29, T. 16 N., R. 10 W., Louisiana Meridian.

paragraph.heading: Original survey.—
paragraph.content: The term “Original Survey” means the survey of land surrounding Lake Bistineau, Louisiana, conducted by the General Land Office in 1838 and approved by the Surveyor General on December 8, 1842.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Consistent with the first section of the Act of December 22, 1928 (commonly known as the “Color of Title Act”) (45 Stat. 1069, chapter 47; 43 U.S.C. 1068), except as provided by this section, the Secretary shall convey to the claimant the omitted land, including any mineral interests, that has been held in good faith and in peaceful, adverse possession by a claimant or an ancestor or grantor of the claimant, under claim or color of title, based on the Original Survey.

paragraph.heading: Confirmation of title.—
paragraph.content: The conveyance or patent of omitted land to a claimant under paragraph (1) shall have the effect of confirming title to the surface and minerals in the claimant and shall not serve as any admission by a claimant.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (2), the conveyance required under subsection (b) shall be without consideration.

paragraph.heading: Condition.—
paragraph.content: As a condition of the conveyance of the omitted land under subsection (b), before making the conveyance, the Secretary shall recover from the State of Louisiana any costs incurred by the Secretary relating to any survey, platting, legal description, or associated activities required to prepare and issue a patent under that subsection.

subsection.heading: Map and legal description.—
subsection.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall file, and make available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land and Management, the Map and legal descriptions of the omitted land to be conveyed under subsection (b).

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: County.—
paragraph.content: The term “County” means Fannin County, Texas.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “map” means the map entitled “Lake Fannin Conveyance” and dated November 21, 2013.

paragraph.heading: National Forest System land.—
paragraph.content: The term “National Forest System land” means the approximately 2,025 acres of National Forest System land generally depicted on the map.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Subject to the terms and conditions described in paragraph (2), if the County submits to the Secretary an offer to acquire the National Forest System land for the fair market value, as determined by the appraisal under paragraph (3), the Secretary shall convey the National Forest System land to the County.

paragraph.heading: Terms and conditions.—
paragraph.chapeau: The conveyance under paragraph (1) shall be—

subparagraph.content: subject to valid existing rights;
made by quitclaim deed; and
subject to any other terms and conditions as the Secretary considers appropriate to protect the interests of the United States.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall complete an appraisal to determine the fair market value of the National Forest System land.

subparagraph.heading: Standards.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The appraisal under subparagraph (A) shall be conducted in accordance with—

clause.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions; and
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

subparagraph.heading: Availability of map.—
subparagraph.content: The map shall be kept on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate office of the Forest Service.

subparagraph.heading: Correction of errors.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary may correct minor errors in the map.

paragraph.heading: Consideration.—
paragraph.content: As consideration for the conveyance under paragraph (1), the County shall pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the fair market value of the National Forest System land, as determined by the appraisal under paragraph (3).

paragraph.heading: Survey.—
paragraph.content: The exact acreage and legal description of the National Forest System land to be conveyed under paragraph (1) shall be determined by a survey satisfactory to the Secretary and the County.

paragraph.heading: Use.—
paragraph.content: As a condition of the conveyance under paragraph (1), the County shall agree to manage the land conveyed under that subsection for public recreational purposes.

paragraph.heading: Costs of conveyance.—
paragraph.chapeau: As a condition on the conveyance under paragraph (1), the County shall pay to the Secretary all costs associated with the conveyance, including the cost of—

subparagraph.content: the appraisal under paragraph (3); and
the survey under paragraph (6).

section.heading: Land conveyance and utility right-of-way, Henry’s Lake Wilderness Study Area, Idaho

subsection.heading: Conveyance and right-of-Way authorized.—
subsection.chapeau: Notwithstanding section 603(c) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1782(c)), the Secretary may—

paragraph.content: convey to the owner of a private residence located at 3787 Valhalla Road in Island Park, Idaho (in this section referred to as the “owner”), all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the approximately 0.5 acres of Federal land in the Henry’s Lake Wilderness Study Area described as lot 14, section 33, Township 16 North, Range 43 East, Boise Meridian, Fremont County, Idaho; and

grant Fall River Electric in Ashton, Idaho, the right to operate, maintain, and rehabilitate a right-of-way encumbering approximately 0.4 acres of Federal land in the Henry’s Lake Wilderness Study Area described as lot 15, section 33, Township 16 North, Range 43 East, Boise Meridian, Fremont County, Idaho, which includes an electric distribution line and access road, 850′ in length, 20′ in width.

paragraph.heading: Land disposal.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall convey the land under subsection (a)(1) in accordance with section 203 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1713) and part 2711.3–3 of title 43, Code of Federal Regulations. As consideration for the conveyance the owner shall pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the fair market value as valued by a qualified land appraisal and approved by the Appraisal and Valuation Services Office.

paragraph.heading: Right-of-way.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall grant the right-of-way granted under subsection (a)(2) in accordance with section 205 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1715), and part 2800 of title 43, Code of Federal Regulations.

subsection.heading: Additional terms and conditions.—
subsection.content: The Secretary may require such additional terms and conditions in connection with the conveyance of the land and the grant of the right-of-way under this section as the Secretary considers appropriate to protect the interests of the United States.

subsection.heading: In general.—
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, subject to valid existing rights, the Secretary shall convey to the Ukpeagvik Inupiat Corporation all right, title, and interest held by the United States in and to sand and gravel deposits underlying the surface estate owned by the Ukpeagvik Inupiat Corporation within and contiguous to the Barrow gas fields, and more particularly described as follows:

paragraph.content: T. 21 N. R. 16 W., secs. 7, 17–18, 19–21, and 28–29, of the Umiat Meridian.
T. 21 N. R. 17 W., secs. 1–2 and 11–14, of the Umiat Meridian.
T. 22 N. R. 18 W., secs. 4, 9, and 29–32, of the Umiat Meridian.
T. 22 N. R. 19 W., secs. 25 and 36, of the Umiat Meridian.

subsection.heading: Entitlement fulfilled.—
subsection.content: The conveyance under this section shall fulfill the entitlement granted to the Ukpeagvik Inupiat Corporation under section 12(a) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (43 U.S.C. 1611(a)).

subsection.heading: Compliance with Endangered Species Act of 1973.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section affects any requirement, prohibition, or exception under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 (16 U.S.C. 1531 et seq.).

section.heading: Public purpose conveyance to City of Hyde Park, Utah

subsection.heading: In general.—
subsection.content: Notwithstanding the land use planning requirement of sections 202 and 203 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1712, 1713), on written request by the City of Hyde Park, Utah (referred to in this section as the “City”), the Secretary shall convey, without consideration, to the City the parcel of public land described in subsection (b)(1) for public recreation or other public purposes consistent with uses allowed under the Act of June 14, 1926 (commonly known as the “Recreation and Public Purposes Act”) (43 U.S.C. 869 et seq.).

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The parcel of public land referred to in subsection (a) is the approximately 80-acre parcel identified on the map entitled “Hyde Park Land Conveyance Act” and dated October 23, 2017.

paragraph.heading: Availability of map.—
paragraph.content: The map referred to in paragraph (1) shall be on file and available for public inspection in appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management.

subsection.heading: Survey.—
subsection.content: The exact acreage and legal description of the land to be conveyed under this section shall be determined by a survey satisfactory to the Secretary.

subsection.heading: Conveyance costs.—
subsection.content: As a condition for the conveyance under this section, all costs associated with the conveyance shall be paid by the City.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: County.—
paragraph.content: The term “County” means Juab County, Utah.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service.

paragraph.heading: Nephi Work Center conveyance parcel.—
paragraph.content: The term “Nephi Work Center conveyance parcel” means the parcel of approximately 2.17 acres of National Forest System land in the County, located at 740 South Main Street, Nephi, Utah, as depicted as Tax Lot Numbers #XA00–0545–1111 and #XA00–0545–2 on the map entitled “Nephi Plat B” and dated May 6, 1981.

subsection.heading: Conveyance of Nephi Work Center conveyance parcel, Juab County, Utah.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 1 year after the date on which the Secretary receives a request from the County and subject to valid existing rights and such terms and conditions as are mutually satisfactory to the Secretary and the County, including such additional terms as the Secretary determines to be necessary, the Secretary shall convey to the County without consideration all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the Nephi Work Center conveyance parcel.

paragraph.heading: Costs.—
paragraph.content: Any costs relating to the conveyance under paragraph (1), including processing and transaction costs, shall be paid by the County.

paragraph.heading: Use of land.—
paragraph.chapeau: The land conveyed to the County under paragraph (1) shall be used by the County—

subparagraph.content: to house fire suppression and fuels mitigation personnel;
to facilitate fire suppression and fuels mitigation activities; and
for infrastructure and equipment necessary to carry out subparagraphs (A) and (B).

section.heading: Black Mountain Range and Bullhead City land exchange

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: City.—
paragraph.content: The term “City” means Bullhead City, Arizona.

paragraph.heading: Non-Federal Land.—
paragraph.content: The term “non-Federal Land” means the approximately 1,100 acres of land owned by Bullhead City in the Black Mountain Range generally depicted as “Bullhead City Land to be Exchanged to BLM” on the Map.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “Map” means the map entitled “Bullhead City Land Exchange” and dated August 24, 2018.

paragraph.heading: Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “Federal land” means the approximately 345.2 acres of land in Bullhead City, Arizona, generally depicted as “Federal Land to be exchanged to Bullhead City” on the Map.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: If after December 15, 2020, the City offers to convey to the Secretary all right, title, and interest of the City in and to the non-Federal land, the Secretary shall accept the offer and simultaneously convey to the City all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Land title.—
paragraph.content: Title to the non-Federal land conveyed to the Secretary under this section shall be in a form acceptable to the Secretary and shall conform to the title approval standards of the Attorney General of the United States applicable to land acquisitions by the Federal Government.

paragraph.heading: Exchange costs.—
paragraph.content: The City shall pay for all land survey, appraisal, and other costs to the Secretary as may be necessary to process and consummate the exchange under this section.

paragraph.heading: Appraisals.—
paragraph.chapeau: The values of the lands to be exchanged under this section shall be determined by the Secretary through appraisals performed—

subparagraph.chapeau: in accordance with—

clause.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions;
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice; and
appraisal instructions issued by the Secretary; and

subparagraph.content: by an appraiser mutually agreed to by the Secretary and the City.

paragraph.heading: Equal value exchange.—
paragraph.chapeau: The values of the Federal and non-Federal land parcels exchanged shall be equal, or if they are not equal, shall be equalized as follows:

subparagraph.heading: Surplus of Federal land value.—
subparagraph.content: If the final appraised value of the Federal land exceeds the final appraised value of the non-Federal land, the City shall reduce the amount of land it is requesting from the Federal Government in order to create an equal value in accordance with section 206(b) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1716(b)). Land that is not exchanged because of equalization under this subparagraph shall remain subject to lease under the Act of June 14, 1926 (commonly known as the “Recreation and Public Purposes Act”) (44 Stat. 741, chapter 578; 43 U.S.C. 869 et seq.).

subparagraph.heading: Use of funds.—
subparagraph.chapeau: Any cash equalization moneys received by the Secretary under subparagraph (A) shall be—

clause.content: deposited in the Federal Land Disposal Account established by section 206(a) of the Federal Land Transaction Facilitation Act (43 U.S.C. 2305(a)); and
used in accordance with that Act (43 U.S.C. 2301 et seq.).

subparagraph.heading: Surplus of non-Federal land value.—
subparagraph.content: If the final appraised value of the non-Federal land exceeds the final appraised value of the Federal land, the United States shall not make a cash equalization payment to the City, and surplus value of the non-Federal land shall be considered a donation by the City to the United States for all purposes of law.

subsection.heading: Withdrawal provisions.—
subsection.content: Lands acquired by the Secretary under this section are, upon such acquisition, automatically and permanently withdrawn from all forms of appropriation and disposal under the public land laws (including the mining and mineral leasing laws) and the Geothermal Steam Act of 1930 (30 U.S.C. 1001 et seq.).

paragraph.heading: Minor errors.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary and the City may, by mutual agreement—

subparagraph.content: make minor boundary adjustments to the Federal and non-Federal lands involved in the exchange; and
correct any minor errors in any map, acreage estimate, or description of any land to be exchanged.

paragraph.heading: Conflict.—
paragraph.content: If there is a conflict between a map, an acreage estimate, or a description of land under this section, the map shall control unless the Secretary and the City mutually agree otherwise.

paragraph.heading: Availability.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall file and make available for public inspection in the Arizona headquarters of the Bureau of Land Management a copy of all maps referred to in this section.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: County.—
paragraph.content: The term “County” means Yavapai County, Arizona.

paragraph.heading: Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “Federal land” means all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to approximately 80 acres of land within the Coconino National Forest, in Yavapai County, Arizona, generally depicted as “Coconino National Forest Parcels ‘Federal Land’” on the map.

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “map” means the map entitled “Cottonwood Land Exchange”, with the revision date July 5, 2018\Version 1.

paragraph.heading: Non-Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “non-Federal land” means the approximately 369 acres of land in Yavapai County, Arizona, generally depicted as “Yavapai County Parcels ‘Non-Federal Land’” on the map.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture, unless otherwise specified.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: If the County offers to convey to the Secretary all right, title, and interest of the County in and to the non-Federal land, the Secretary shall accept the offer and simultaneously convey to the County all right, title, and interest of the United States to the Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Land title.—
paragraph.content: Title to the non-Federal land conveyed to the Secretary under this section shall be acceptable to the Secretary and shall conform to the title approval standards of the Attorney General of the United States applicable to land acquisitions by the Federal Government.

paragraph.heading: Exchange costs.—
paragraph.content: The County shall pay for all land survey, appraisal, and other costs to the Secretary as may be necessary to process and consummate the exchange under this section, including reimbursement to the Secretary, if the Secretary so requests, for staff time spent in such processing and consummation.

paragraph.heading: Appraisals.—
paragraph.chapeau: The values of the lands to be exchanged under this section shall be determined by the Secretary through appraisals performed—

subparagraph.chapeau: in accordance with—

clause.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions;
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice; and
appraisal instructions issued by the Secretary; and

subparagraph.content: by an appraiser mutually agreed to by the Secretary and the County.

paragraph.heading: Equal value exchange.—
paragraph.chapeau: The values of the Federal and non-Federal land parcels exchanged shall be equal, or if they are not equal, shall be equalized as follows:

subparagraph.heading: Surplus of Federal land value.—
subparagraph.content: If the final appraised value of the Federal land exceeds the final appraised value of the non-Federal land, the County shall make a cash equalization payment to the United States as necessary to achieve equal value, including, if necessary, an amount in excess of that authorized pursuant to section 206(b) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1716(b)).

subparagraph.heading: Use of funds.—
subparagraph.chapeau: Any cash equalization moneys received by the Secretary under subparagraph (A) shall be—

clause.content: deposited in the fund established under Public Law 90–171 (commonly known as the “Sisk Act”; 16 U.S.C. 484a); and
made available to the Secretary for the acquisition of land or interests in land in Region 3 of the Forest Service.

subparagraph.heading: Surplus of non-Federal land value.—
subparagraph.content: If the final appraised value of the non-Federal land exceeds the final appraised value of the Federal land, the United States shall not make a cash equalization payment to the County, and surplus value of the non-Federal land shall be considered a donation by the County to the United States for all purposes of law.

subsection.heading: Withdrawal provisions.—
subsection.content: Lands acquired by the Secretary under this section are, upon such acquisition, automatically and permanently withdrawn from all forms of appropriation and disposal under the public land laws (including the mining and mineral leasing laws) and the Geothermal Steam Act of 1930 (30 U.S.C. 1001 et seq.).

subsection.heading: Management of land.—
subsection.content: Land acquired by the Secretary under this section shall become part of the Coconino National Forest and be managed in accordance with the laws, rules, and regulations applicable to the National Forest System.

paragraph.heading: Minor errors.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary and the County may, by mutual agreement—

subparagraph.content: make minor boundary adjustments to the Federal and non-Federal lands involved in the exchange; and
correct any minor errors in any map, acreage estimate, or description of any land to be exchanged.

paragraph.heading: Conflict.—
paragraph.content: If there is a conflict between a map, an acreage estimate, or a description of land under this section, the map shall control unless the Secretary and the County mutually agree otherwise.

paragraph.heading: Availability.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall file and make available for public inspection in the headquarters of the Coconino National Forest a copy of all maps referred to in this section.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Non-Federal land.—
paragraph.content: The term “non-Federal land” means the approximately 16-acre parcel of University land identified in section 3(a) of Public Law 105–363 (112 Stat. 3297).

paragraph.heading: University.—
paragraph.content: The term “University” means Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Florida.

subsection.heading: Conveyance of Federal reversionary interest in land located in the county of Yavapai, Arizona.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, if after the completion of the appraisal required under subsection (c), the University submits to the Secretary an offer to acquire the reversionary interests of the United States in and to the non-Federal land, the Secretary shall convey to the University the reversionary interests of the United States in and to the non-Federal land for the purpose of unencumbering the title to the non-Federal land to enable economic development of the non-Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Legal descriptions.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the exact legal description of the non-Federal land shall be determined in a manner satisfactory to the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: Additional terms and conditions.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary may require such additional terms and conditions to the conveyance under paragraph (1), consistent with this section, as the Secretary considers appropriate to protect the interests of the United States.

paragraph.heading: Costs.—
paragraph.content: The University shall pay all costs associated with the conveyance under paragraph (1), including the costs of the appraisal required under subsection (c), the costs of any surveys, recording costs, and other reasonable costs.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall complete an appraisal of the reversionary interests of the United States in and to the non-Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Applicable law.—
paragraph.chapeau: The appraisal shall be completed in accordance with—

subparagraph.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions; and
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: As consideration for the conveyance of the reversionary interests of the United States in and to the non-Federal land under this section, the University shall pay to the Secretary an amount equal to the appraised value of the interests of the United States, as determined under subsection (c).

paragraph.heading: Deposit; use.—
paragraph.chapeau: Amounts received under paragraph (1) shall be—

subparagraph.content: deposited in the Federal Land Disposal Account established by section 206(a) of the Federal Land Transaction Facilitation Act (43 U.S.C. 2305(a)); and
used in accordance with that Act (43 U.S.C. 2301 et seq.).

subtitle.heading: Public land and National Forest System management

subsection.heading: Access granted.—
subsection.content: The Secretary of Agriculture shall permit by special use authorization nonmotorized access and use, in accordance with section 293.6 of title 36, Code of Federal Regulations, of the Bolts Ditch Headgate and the Bolts Ditch within the Holy Cross Wilderness, Colorado, as designated by Public Law 96–560 (94 Stat. 3265), for the purposes of the diversion of water and use, maintenance, and repair of such ditch and headgate by the Town of Minturn, Colorado, a Colorado Home Rule Municipality.

subsection.heading: Location of facilities.—
subsection.content: The Bolts Ditch headgate and ditch segment referenced in subsection (a) are as generally depicted on the map entitled “Bolts Ditch headgate and Ditch Segment” and dated November 2015.

section.heading: Clarification relating to a certain land description under the Northern Arizona Land Exchange and Verde River Basin Partnership Act of 2005
section.content: Section 104(a)(5) of the Northern Arizona Land Exchange and Verde River Basin Partnership Act of 2005 (Public Law 109–110; 119 Stat. 2356) is amended by inserting before the period at the end “, which, notwithstanding section 102(a)(4)(B), includes the N1/2 NE1⁄4 SW1⁄4 SW1⁄4, the N1⁄2 N1⁄2 SE1⁄4 SW1⁄4, and the N1⁄2 N1⁄2 SW1⁄4 SE1⁄4, sec. 34, Township 22 North, Range 2 East, Gila and Salt River Meridian, Coconino County, Arizona, comprising approximately 25 acres”.

section.heading: Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area

subsection.heading: Findings.—
subsection.chapeau: Congress finds that—

paragraph.content: Frank Moore has committed his life to family, friends, his country, and fly fishing;

Frank Moore is a World War II veteran who stormed the beaches of Normandy along with 150,000 troops during the D-Day Allied invasion and was awarded the Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor for his bravery;
Frank Moore returned home after the war, started a family, and pursued his passion of fishing on the winding rivers in Oregon;

as the proprietor of the Steamboat Inn along the North Umpqua River in Oregon for nearly 20 years, Frank Moore, along with his wife Jeanne, shared his love of fishing, the flowing river, and the great outdoors, with visitors from all over the United States and the world;

Frank Moore has spent most of his life fishing the vast rivers of Oregon, during which time he has contributed significantly to efforts to conserve fish habitats and protect river health, including serving on the State of Oregon Fish and Wildlife Commission;

Frank Moore has been recognized for his conservation work with the National Wildlife Federation Conservationist of the Year award, the Wild Steelhead Coalition Conservation Award, and his 2010 induction into the Fresh Water Fishing Hall of Fame; and

in honor of the many accomplishments of Frank Moore, both on and off the river, approximately 99,653 acres of Forest Service land in the State of Oregon should be designated as the “Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area”.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “Map” means the map entitled “Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area Designation Act” and dated June 23, 2016.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service.

paragraph.heading: Special management area.—
paragraph.content: The term “Special Management Area” means the Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area designated by subsection (c)(1).

paragraph.heading: State.—
paragraph.content: The term “State” means the State of Oregon.

subsection.heading: Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area, Oregon.—

paragraph.heading: Designation.—
paragraph.content: The approximately 99,653 acres of Forest Service land in the State, as generally depicted on the Map, is designated as the “Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area”.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall prepare a map and legal description of the Special Management Area.

subparagraph.heading: Force of law.—
subparagraph.content: The map and legal description prepared under subparagraph (A) shall have the same force and effect as if included in this section, except that the Secretary may correct clerical and typographical errors in the map and legal description.

subparagraph.heading: Availability.—
subparagraph.content: The map and legal description prepared under subparagraph (A) shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Forest Service.

paragraph.heading: Administration.—
paragraph.chapeau: Subject to valid existing rights, the Special Management Area shall be administered by the Secretary—

subparagraph.content: in accordance with all laws (including regulations) applicable to the National Forest System; and

subparagraph.chapeau: in a manner that—

clause.content: conserves and enhances the natural character, scientific use, and the botanical, recreational, ecological, fish and wildlife, scenic, drinking water, and cultural values of the Special Management Area;
maintains and seeks to enhance the wild salmonid habitat of the Special Management Area;
maintains or enhances the watershed as a thermal refuge for wild salmonids; and
preserves opportunities for recreation, including primitive recreation.

paragraph.heading: Fish and wildlife.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section affects the jurisdiction or responsibilities of the State with respect to fish and wildlife in the State.

paragraph.heading: Adjacent management.—
paragraph.chapeau: Nothing in this section—

subparagraph.content: creates any protective perimeter or buffer zone around the Special Management Area; or
modifies the applicable travel management plan for the Special Management Area.

paragraph.heading: Wildfire management.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section prohibits the Secretary, in cooperation with other Federal, State, and local agencies, as appropriate, from conducting wildland fire operations in the Special Management Area, consistent with the purposes of this section, including the use of aircraft, machinery, mechanized equipment, fire breaks, backfires, and retardant.

paragraph.heading: Vegetation management.—
paragraph.chapeau: Nothing in this section prohibits the Secretary from conducting vegetation management projects within the Special Management Area in a manner consistent with—

subparagraph.content: the purposes described in paragraph (3); and
the applicable forest plan.

paragraph.heading: Protection of tribal rights.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section diminishes any treaty rights of an Indian Tribe.

paragraph.heading: Withdrawal.—
paragraph.chapeau: Subject to valid existing rights, the Federal land within the boundaries of the Special Management Area river segments designated by paragraph (1) is withdrawn from all forms of—

subparagraph.content: entry, appropriation, or disposal under the public land laws;
location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and
disposition under all laws relating to mineral and geothermal leasing or mineral materials.

section.heading: Maintenance or replacement of facilities and structures at Smith Gulch
section.chapeau: The authorization of the Secretary of Agriculture to maintain or replace facilities or structures for commercial recreation services at Smith Gulch under section 3(a)(24)(D) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act (16 U.S.C. 1274(a)(24)(D))—

paragraph.chapeau: may include improvements or replacements that the Secretary of Agriculture determines—

subparagraph.content: are consistent with section 9(b) of the Central Idaho Wilderness Act of 1980 (16 U.S.C. 1281 note; Public Law 96–312); and
would reduce the impact of the commercial recreation facilities or services on wilderness or wild and scenic river resources and values; and

paragraph.chapeau: authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to consider including, as appropriate—

subparagraph.content: hydroelectric generators and associated electrical transmission facilities;
water pumps for fire suppression;
transitions from propane to electrical lighting;
solar energy systems;
6-volt or 12-volt battery banks for power storage; and
other improvements or replacements which are consistent with this section that the Secretary of Agriculture determines appropriate.

section.heading: Repeal of provision limiting the export of timber harvested from certain Kake Tribal Corporation land
section.chapeau: Section 42 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (43 U.S.C. 1629h) is amended—

paragraph.content: by striking subsection (h);
by redesignating subsection (i) as subsection (h); and
in subsection (h) (as so redesignated), in the first sentence, by striking “and to provide” and all that follows through “subsection (h)”.

section.heading: Designation of Fowler and Boskoff Peaks

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The 13,498-foot mountain peak, located at 37.8569° N, by −108.0117° W, in the Uncompahgre National Forest in the State of Colorado, shall be known and designated as “Fowler Peak”.

paragraph.heading: References.—
paragraph.content: Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the peak described in paragraph (1) shall be deemed to be a reference to “Fowler Peak”.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The 13,123-foot mountain peak, located at 37.85549° N, by −108.03112° W, in the Uncompahgre National Forest in the State of Colorado, shall be known and designated as “Boskoff Peak”.

paragraph.heading: References.—
paragraph.content: Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the peak described in paragraph (1) shall be deemed to be a reference to “Boskoff Peak”.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The term “permittee” means a person who, on the date of enactment of this Act, holds a valid permit for use of a property.

subparagraph.heading: Inclusions.—
subparagraph.content: The term “permittee” includes any heirs, executors, and assigns of the permittee or interest of the permittee.

paragraph.heading: Property.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “property” means—

subparagraph.content: the approximately 1.1 acres of National Forest System land in sec. 8, T. 10 S., R. 16 E., Gila and Salt River Meridian, as generally depicted on the map entitled “Coronado National Forest Land Conveyance Act of 2017”, special use permit numbered SAN5005–03, and dated October 2017;

the approximately 4.5 acres of National Forest System land in sec. 8, T. 10 S., R. 16 E., Gila and Salt River Meridian, as generally depicted on the map entitled “Coronado National Forest Land Conveyance Act of 2017”, special use permit numbered SAN5116–03, and dated October 2017; and

the approximately 3.9 acres of National Forest System land in NW¼, sec. 1, T. 10 S., R. 15 E., Gila and Salt River Meridian, as generally depicted on the map entitled “Coronado National Forest Land Conveyance Act of 2017”, special use permit numbered SAN5039–02, and dated October 2017.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: Subject to valid existing rights, during the period described in paragraph (2), not later than 90 days after the date on which a permittee submits a request to the Secretary, the Secretary shall—

subparagraph.content: accept tender of consideration from that permittee; and
sell and quitclaim to that permittee all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to the property for which the permittee holds a permit.

paragraph.heading: Period described.—
paragraph.content: The period referred to in paragraph (1) is the period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act and ending on the date of expiration of the applicable permit.

subsection.heading: Terms and conditions.—
subsection.content: The Secretary may establish such terms and conditions on the sales of the properties under this section as the Secretary determines to be in the public interest.

subsection.heading: Consideration.—
subsection.content: A sale of a property under this section shall be for cash consideration equal to the market value of the property, as determined by the appraisal described in subsection (e).

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall complete an appraisal of each property, which shall—

subparagraph.content: include the value of any appurtenant easements; and
exclude the value of any private improvements made by a permittee of the property before the date of appraisal.

paragraph.heading: Standards.—
paragraph.chapeau: An appraisal under paragraph (1) shall be conducted in accordance with—

subparagraph.content: the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions, established in accordance with the Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property Acquisition Policies Act of 1970 (42 U.S.C. 4601 et seq.); and
the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

subsection.heading: Costs.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary shall pay—

paragraph.content: the cost of a conveyance of a property under this section; and
the cost of an appraisal under subsection (e).

subsection.heading: Proceeds from the sale of land.—
subsection.content: Any payment received by the Secretary from the sale of property under this section shall be deposited in the fund established under Public Law 90–171 (commonly known as the “Sisk Act”) (16 U.S.C. 484a) and shall be available to the Secretary until expended for the acquisition of inholdings in national forests in the State of Arizona.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall file maps and legal descriptions of each property.

paragraph.heading: Force of law.—
paragraph.content: The maps and legal descriptions filed under paragraph (1) shall have the same force and effect as if included in this section, except that the Secretary may correct typographical errors in the maps and legal descriptions.

paragraph.heading: Public availability.—
paragraph.content: The maps and legal descriptions filed under paragraph (1) shall be on file and available for public inspection in the office of the Supervisor of the Coronado National Forest.

section.heading: Deschutes Canyon-Steelhead Falls Wilderness Study Area boundary adjustment, Oregon

subsection.heading: Boundary adjustment.—
subsection.content: The boundary of the Deschutes Canyon-Steelhead Falls Wilderness Study Area is modified to exclude approximately 688 acres of public land, as depicted on the map entitled “Deschutes Canyon-Steelhead Falls Wilderness Study Area (WSA) Proposed Boundary Adjustment” and dated September 26, 2018.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: The public land excluded from the Deschutes Canyon-Steelhead Falls Wilderness Study Area under subsection (a)—

subparagraph.content: is no longer subject to section 603(c) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1782(c)); and

subparagraph.chapeau: shall be managed in accordance with—

clause.content: this section;
the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.); and
any applicable resource management plan.

paragraph.heading: Management.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall manage the land excluded from the Deschutes Canyon-Steelhead Falls Wilderness Study Area under subsection (a) to improve fire resiliency and forest health, including the conduct of wildfire prevention and response activities, as appropriate.

paragraph.heading: Off-road recreational motorized use.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall not permit off-road recreational motorized use on the public land excluded from the Deschutes Canyon-Steelhead Falls Wilderness Study Area under subsection (a).

section.heading: Maintenance of Federal mineral leases based on extraction of helium
section.content: The first section of the Mineral Leasing Act (30 U.S.C. 181) is amended in the fifth paragraph by inserting after “purchaser thereof” the following: “, and that extraction of helium from gas produced from such lands shall maintain the lease as if the extracted helium were oil and gas”.

section.heading: Small miner waivers to claim maintenance fees

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Covered claimholder.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “covered claimholder” means—

subparagraph.content: the claimholder of the claims in the State numbered AA023149, AA023163, AA047913, AA047914, AA047915, AA047916, AA047917, AA047918, and AA047919 (as of December 29, 2004);
the claimholder of the claim in the State numbered FF–059315 (as of December 29, 2004);
the claimholder of the claims in the State numbered FF–58607, FF–58608, FF–58609, FF–58610, FF–58611, FF–58613, FF–58615, FF–58616, FF–58617, and FF–58618 (as of December 31, 2003); and
the claimholder of the claims in the State numbered FF–53988, FF–53989, and FF–53990 (as of December 31, 1987).

paragraph.heading: Defect.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “defect” includes a failure—

subparagraph.chapeau: to timely file—

clause.content: a small miner maintenance fee waiver application;
an affidavit of annual labor associated with a small miner maintenance fee waiver application; or
an instrument required under section 314(a) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1744(a)); and

subparagraph.content: to pay the required application fee for a small maintenance fee waiver application.

paragraph.heading: State.—
paragraph.content: The term “State” means the State of Alaska.
