subsection.heading: Treatment of covered claimholders.—
subsection.chapeau: Notwithstanding section 10101(d) of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (30 U.S.C. 28f(d)) and section 314(c) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1744(c)), each covered claimholder shall, during the 60-day period beginning on the date on which the covered claimholder receives written notification from the Bureau of Land Management by registered mail of the opportunity, have the opportunity—

subparagraph.content: to cure any defect in a small miner maintenance fee waiver application (including the failure to timely file a small miner maintenance fee waiver application) for any prior period during which the defect existed; or
to pay any claim maintenance fees due for any prior period during which the defect existed; and

paragraph.content: to cure any defect in the filing of any instrument required under section 314(a) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1744(a)) (including the failure to timely file any required instrument) for any prior period during which the defect existed.

subsection.heading: Reinstatement of claims deemed forfeited.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary shall reinstate any claim of a covered claimholder as of the date declared forfeited and void—

paragraph.content: under section 10104 of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (30 U.S.C. 28i) for failure to pay the claim maintenance fee or obtain a valid waiver under section 10101 of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (30 U.S.C. 28f); or

paragraph.chapeau: under section 314(c) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1744(c)) for failure to file any instrument required under section 314(a) of that Act (43 U.S.C. 1744(a)) for any prior period during which the defect existed if the covered claimholder—

subparagraph.content: cures the defect; or
pays the claim maintenance fee under subsection (b)(1)(B).

section.heading: Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Memorial and National Monument

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Memorial.—
paragraph.content: The term “Memorial” means the Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Memorial authorized under subsection (b)(1).

paragraph.heading: Monument.—
paragraph.content: The term “Monument” means the Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Monument established by subsection (d)(1).

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture.

paragraph.heading: State.—
paragraph.content: The term “State” means the State of California.

subsection.heading: Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Memorial.—

paragraph.heading: Establishment.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary may establish a memorial at the Saint Francis Dam site in the county of Los Angeles, California, for the purpose of honoring the victims of the Saint Francis Dam disaster of March 12, 1928.

paragraph.heading: Requirements.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Memorial shall be—

subparagraph.content: known as the “Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Memorial”; and
managed by the Forest Service.

paragraph.heading: Donations.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary may accept, hold, administer, invest, and spend any gift, devise, or bequest of real or personal property made to the Secretary for purposes of developing, designing, constructing, and managing the Memorial.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to Congress recommendations regarding—

subparagraph.content: the planning, design, construction, and long-term management of the Memorial;
the proposed boundaries of the Memorial;
a visitor center and educational facilities at the Memorial; and
ensuring public access to the Memorial.

paragraph.heading: Consultation.—
paragraph.chapeau: In preparing the recommendations required under paragraph (1), the Secretary shall consult with—

subparagraph.content: appropriate Federal agencies;
State, Tribal, and local governments, including the Santa Clarita City Council; and
the public.

subsection.heading: Establishment of Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Monument.—

paragraph.heading: Establishment.—
paragraph.content: There is established as a national monument in the State certain National Forest System land administered by the Secretary in the county of Los Angeles, California, comprising approximately 353 acres, as generally depicted on the map entitled “Proposed Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Monument” and dated September 12, 2018, to be known as the “Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Monument”.

paragraph.heading: Purpose.—
paragraph.content: The purpose of the Monument is to conserve and enhance for the benefit and enjoyment of the public the cultural, archaeological, historical, watershed, educational, and recreational resources and values of the Monument.

subsection.heading: Duties of the Secretary with respect to Monument.—

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 4 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall develop a management plan for the Monument.

subparagraph.heading: Consultation.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The management plan shall be developed in consultation with—

clause.content: appropriate Federal agencies;
State, Tribal, and local governments; and
the public.

subparagraph.heading: Considerations.—
subparagraph.content: In developing and implementing the management plan, the Secretary shall, with respect to methods of protecting and providing access to the Monument, consider the recommendations of the Saint Francis Disaster National Memorial Foundation, the Santa Clarita Valley Historical Society, and the Community Hiking Club of Santa Clarita.

paragraph.heading: Management.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall manage the Monument—

subparagraph.content: in a manner that conserves and enhances the cultural and historic resources of the Monument; and

subparagraph.chapeau: in accordance with—

clause.content: the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 (16 U.S.C. 1600 et seq.);
the laws generally applicable to the National Forest System;
this section; and
any other applicable laws.

subparagraph.heading: Use of motorized vehicles.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The use of motorized vehicles within the Monument may be permitted only—

clause.content: on roads designated for use by motorized vehicles in the management plan required under paragraph (1);
for administrative purposes; or
for emergency responses.

subparagraph.heading: Grazing.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall permit grazing within the Monument, where established before the date of enactment of this Act—

clause.content: subject to all applicable laws (including regulations and Executive orders); and
consistent with the purpose described in subsection (d)(2).

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Nothing in this section creates a protective perimeter or buffer zone around the Monument.

subparagraph.heading: Activities outside national monument.—
subparagraph.content: The fact that an activity or use on land outside the Monument can be seen or heard within the Monument shall not preclude the activity or use outside the boundary of the Monument.

paragraph.heading: Use of existing funds.—
paragraph.content: This section shall be carried out using amounts otherwise made available to the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: No additional funds.—
paragraph.content: No additional funds are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section.

subsection.heading: Effect.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section affects the operation, maintenance, replacement, or modification of existing water resource, flood control, utility, pipeline, or telecommunications facilities that are located outside the boundary of the Monument, subject to the special use authorities of the Secretary of Agriculture and other applicable laws.

paragraph.heading: North Fork Owyhee Wilderness.—
paragraph.chapeau: The boundary of the North Fork Owyhee Wilderness established by section 1503(a)(1)(D) of the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 (Public Law 111–11; 123 Stat. 1033) is modified to exclude certain land, as depicted on—

subparagraph.content: the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “North Fork Owyhee and Pole Creek Wilderness Aerial” and dated July 19, 2016; and
the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “North Fork Owyhee River Wilderness Big Springs Camp Zoom Aerial” and dated July 19, 2016.

paragraph.heading: Owyhee River Wilderness.—
paragraph.chapeau: The boundary of the Owyhee River Wilderness established by section 1503(a)(1)(E) of the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 (Public Law 111–11; 123 Stat. 1033) is modified to exclude certain land, as depicted on—

subparagraph.content: the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “North Fork Owyhee, Pole Creek, and Owyhee River Wilderness Aerial” and dated July 19, 2016;
the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “Owyhee River Wilderness Kincaid Reservoir Zoom Aerial” and dated July 19, 2016; and
the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “Owyhee River Wilderness Dickshooter Road Zoom Aerial” and dated July 19, 2016.

paragraph.heading: Pole Creek Wilderness.—
paragraph.chapeau: The boundary of the Pole Creek Wilderness established by section 1503(a)(1)(F) of the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 (Public Law 111–11; 123 Stat. 1033) is modified to exclude certain land, as depicted on—

subparagraph.content: the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “North Fork Owyhee, Pole Creek, and Owyhee River Wilderness Aerial” and dated July 19, 2016; and
the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “Pole Creek Wilderness Pullout Zoom Aerial” and dated July 19, 2016.

paragraph.heading: Effect.—
paragraph.content: The maps referred to in subsection (a) shall have the same force and effect as if included in this Act, except that the Secretary may correct minor errors in the maps.

paragraph.heading: Availability.—
paragraph.content: The maps referred to in subsection (a) shall be available in the appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: CAC.—
paragraph.content: The term “CAC” means the Chugach Alaska Corporation.

paragraph.heading: CAC land.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “CAC land” means land conveyed to CAC pursuant to the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (43 U.S.C. 1601 et seq.) under which—

subparagraph.content: both the surface estate and the subsurface estate were conveyed to CAC; or

clause.content: the subsurface estate was conveyed to CAC; and
the surface estate or a conservation easement in the surface estate was acquired by the State or by the United States as part of the program.

paragraph.heading: Program.—
paragraph.content: The term “program” means the Habitat Protection and Acquisition Program of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council.

paragraph.heading: Region.—
paragraph.content: The term “Region” means the Chugach Region, Alaska.

paragraph.heading: Study.—
paragraph.content: The term “study” means the study conducted under subsection (b)(1).

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Agriculture and in consultation with CAC, shall conduct a study of land ownership and use patterns in the Region.

paragraph.heading: Study requirements.—
paragraph.chapeau: The study shall—

subparagraph.chapeau: assess the social and economic impacts of the program, including impacts caused by split estate ownership patterns created by Federal acquisitions under the program, on—

clause.content: the Region; and
CAC and CAC land;

subparagraph.content: identify sufficient acres of accessible and economically viable Federal land that can be offered in exchange for CAC land identified by CAC as available for exchange; and

subparagraph.chapeau: provide recommendations for land exchange options with CAC that would—

clause.content: consolidate ownership of the surface and mineral estate of Federal land under the program; and
convey to CAC Federal land identified under subparagraph (B).

subsection.heading: Report.—
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate and the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives a report describing the results of the study, including—

paragraph.content: a recommendation on options for 1 or more land exchanges; and

paragraph.chapeau: detailed information on—

subparagraph.content: the acres of Federal land identified for exchange; and
any other recommendations provided by the Secretary.

subsection.heading: Purpose.—
subsection.chapeau: The purpose of this section is to promote the use of the best available technology to enhance the effective and cost-efficient response to wildfires—

paragraph.content: to meet applicable protection objectives; and

paragraph.chapeau: to increase the safety of—

subparagraph.content: firefighters; and
the public.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Secretaries.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “Secretaries” means—

subparagraph.content: the Secretary of Agriculture; and
the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: Secretary concerned.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “Secretary concerned” means—

subparagraph.content: the Secretary of Agriculture, with respect to activities under the Department of Agriculture; and
the Secretary, with respect to activities under the Department of the Interior.

paragraph.heading: Definitions.—
paragraph.content: In this subsection, the terms “unmanned aircraft” and “unmanned aircraft system” have the meanings given those terms in section 44801 of title 49, United States Code.

paragraph.heading: Establishment of program.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, shall establish a research, development, and testing program, or expand an applicable existing program, to assess unmanned aircraft system technologies, including optionally piloted aircraft, across the full range of wildland fire management operations in order to accelerate the deployment and integration of those technologies into the operations of the Secretaries.

paragraph.heading: Expanding use of unmanned aircraft systems on wildfires.—
paragraph.content: In carrying out the program established under paragraph (2), the Secretaries, in coordination with the Federal Aviation Administration, State wildland firefighting agencies, and other relevant Federal agencies, shall enter into an agreement under which the Secretaries shall develop consistent protocols and plans for the use on wildland fires of unmanned aircraft system technologies, including for the development of real-time maps of the location of wildland fires.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, subject to the availability of appropriations, the Secretaries, in coordination with State wildland firefighting agencies, shall jointly develop and operate a tracking system (referred to in this subsection as the “system”) to remotely locate the positions of fire resources for use by wildland firefighters, including, at a minimum, any fire resources assigned to Federal type 1 wildland fire incident management teams.

paragraph.heading: Requirements.—
paragraph.chapeau: The system shall—

subparagraph.content: use the most practical and effective technology available to the Secretaries to remotely track the location of an active resource, such as a Global Positioning System;
depict the location of each fire resource on the applicable maps developed under subsection (c)(3);
operate continuously during the period for which any firefighting personnel are assigned to the applicable Federal wildland fire; and
be subject to such terms and conditions as the Secretary concerned determines necessary for the effective implementation of the system.

paragraph.heading: Operation.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary concerned shall—

subparagraph.chapeau: before commencing operation of the system—

clause.content: conduct not fewer than 2 pilot projects relating to the operation, management, and effectiveness of the system; and
review the results of those pilot projects;

subparagraph.content: conduct training, and maintain a culture, such that an employee, officer, or contractor shall not rely on the system for safety; and

subparagraph.chapeau: establish procedures for the collection, storage, and transfer of data collected under this subsection to ensure—

clause.content: data security; and
the privacy of wildland fire personnel.

paragraph.heading: Protocol.—
paragraph.chapeau: To the maximum extent practicable, the Secretaries shall ensure that wildland fire management activities conducted by the Secretaries, or conducted jointly by the Secretaries and State wildland firefighting agencies, achieve compliance with applicable incident management objectives in a manner that—

subparagraph.content: minimizes firefighter exposure to the lowest level necessary; and
reduces overall costs of wildfire incidents.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretaries, in coordination with State wildland firefighting agencies, shall establish a system or expand an existing system to track and monitor decisions made by the Secretaries or State wildland firefighting agencies in managing wildfires.

subparagraph.heading: Components.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The system established or expanded under subparagraph (A) shall be able to alert the Secretaries if—

clause.content: unusual costs are incurred;

clause.chapeau: an action to be carried out would likely—

subclause.content: endanger the safety of a firefighter; or
be ineffective in meeting an applicable suppression or protection goal; or

clause.chapeau: a decision regarding the management of a wildfire deviates from—

subclause.content: an applicable protocol established by the Secretaries, including the requirement under paragraph (1); or
an applicable spatial fire management plan or fire management plan of the Secretary concerned.

subsection.heading: Smoke projections from active wildland fires.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretaries shall establish a program, to be known as the “Interagency Wildland Fire Air Quality Response Program”, under which the Secretary concerned—

paragraph.content: to the maximum extent practicable, shall assign 1 or more air resource advisors to a type 1 incident management team managing a Federal wildland fire; and
may assign 1 or more air resource advisors to a type 2 incident management team managing a wildland fire.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: Section 9(a) of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 (15 U.S.C. 2208(a)) is amended—

subparagraph.content: in paragraph (2), by inserting “, categorized by the type of fire” after “such injuries and deaths”; and

in paragraph (3), by striking “activities;” and inserting the following: “activities, including—“(A) all injuries sustained by a firefighter and treated by a doctor, categorized by the type of firefighter;“(B) all deaths sustained while undergoing a pack test or preparing for a work capacity;“(C) all injuries or deaths resulting from vehicle accidents; and“(D) all injuries or deaths resulting from aircraft crashes;”.

paragraph.heading: Use of existing data gathering and analysis organizations.—
paragraph.content: Section 9(b)(3) of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 (15 U.S.C. 2208(b)(3)) is amended by inserting “, including the Center for Firefighter Injury Research and Safety Trends” after “public and private”.

paragraph.heading: Medical privacy of firefighters.—
paragraph.content: Section 9 of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 (15 U.S.C. 2208) is amended by adding at the end the following:“(e) Medical privacy of firefighters.—The collection, storage, and transfer of any medical data collected under this section shall be conducted in accordance with—“(1) the privacy regulations promulgated under section 264(c) of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (42 U.S.C. 1320d–2 note; Public Law 104–191); and“(2) other applicable regulations, including parts 160, 162, and 164 of title 45, Code of Federal Regulations (as in effect on the date of enactment of this subsection).”.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Secretaries, in consultation with the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Secretary of Commerce, shall establish and maintain a database, to be known as the “Rapid Response Erosion Database” (referred to in this subsection as the “Database”).

subparagraph.heading: Availability.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretaries shall make the Database (including the original source code)—

clause.content: web-based; and
available without charge.

subparagraph.heading: Components.—
subparagraph.chapeau: To the maximum extent practicable, the Database shall provide for—

clause.content: the automatic incorporation of spatial data relating to vegetation, soils, and elevation into an applicable map created by the Secretary concerned that depicts the changes in land-cover and soil properties caused by a wildland fire; and

the generation of a composite map that can be used by the Secretary concerned to model the effectiveness of treatments in the burned area to prevent flooding, erosion, and landslides under a range of weather scenarios.

paragraph.heading: Use.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary concerned shall use the Database, as applicable, in developing recommendations for emergency stabilization treatments or modifications to drainage structures to protect values-at-risk following a wildland fire.

paragraph.heading: Coordination.—
paragraph.content: The Secretaries may share the Database, and any results generated in using the Database, with any State or unit of local government.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Secretaries, in consultation with the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Secretary of Energy, and the Secretary of Commerce, through the capabilities and assets located at the National Laboratories, shall establish and maintain a system to predict the locations of future wildfires for fire-prone areas of the United States.

paragraph.heading: Cooperation; components.—
paragraph.content: The system established under paragraph (1) shall be based on, and seek to enhance, similar systems in existence on the date of enactment of this Act, including the Fire Danger Assessment System.

paragraph.heading: Use in forecasts.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretaries shall use the system established under paragraph (1), to the maximum extent practicable, for purposes of developing any wildland fire potential forecasts.

paragraph.heading: Coordination.—
paragraph.content: The Secretaries may share the system established under paragraph (1), and any results generated in using the system, with any State or unit of local government.

subsection.heading: Termination of authority.—
subsection.content: The authority provided by this section terminates on the date that is 10 years after the date of enactment of this Act.

subsection.heading: Savings Clause.—
subsection.chapeau: Nothing in this section—

paragraph.content: requires the Secretary concerned to establish a new program, system, or database to replace an existing program, system, or database that meets the objectives of this section; or

paragraph.chapeau: precludes the Secretary concerned from using existing or future technology that—

subparagraph.content: is more efficient, safer, or better meets the needs of firefighters, other personnel, or the public; and
meets the objectives of this section.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: County.—
paragraph.content: The term “County” means Uintah County, Utah.

paragraph.heading: Decision Record.—
paragraph.content: The term “Decision Record” means the Decision Record prepared by the Bureau of Land Management for the Environmental Assessment for the McCoy Flats Trail System numbered DOI–BLM–G010–2012–0057 and dated October 2012.

paragraph.heading: State.—
paragraph.content: The term “State” means the State of Utah.

paragraph.heading: Trail system.—
paragraph.content: The term “Trail System” means the McCoy Flats Trail System established by subsection (b)(1).

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Subject to valid existing rights, there is established the McCoy Flats Trail System in the State.

paragraph.heading: Area included.—
paragraph.content: The Trail System shall include public land administered by the Bureau of Land Management in the County, as described in the Decision Record.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall prepare a map and legal description of the Trail System.

paragraph.heading: Availability; transmittal to Congress.—
paragraph.chapeau: The map and legal description prepared under paragraph (1) shall be—

subparagraph.content: available in appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management; and

subparagraph.chapeau: transmitted by the Secretary to—

clause.content: the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives; and
the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate.

paragraph.heading: Force and effect.—
paragraph.content: The map and legal description prepared under paragraph (1) shall have the same force and effect as if included in this section, except that the Secretary may correct any clerical or typographical errors in the map and legal description.

subsection.heading: Administration.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary shall administer the Trail System in accordance with—

paragraph.content: the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.);
this section; and
other applicable law.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation and coordination with the County and affected Indian Tribes, shall prepare a management plan for the Trail System.

paragraph.heading: Public comment.—
paragraph.content: The management plan shall be developed with opportunities for public comment.

paragraph.heading: Interim management.—
paragraph.content: Until the completion of the management plan, the Trail System shall be administered in accordance with the Decision Record.

paragraph.heading: Recreational opportunities.—
paragraph.content: In developing the management plan, the Secretary shall seek to provide for new mountain bike route and trail construction to increase recreational opportunities within the Trail System, consistent with this section.

subsection.heading: Uses.—
subsection.content: The Trail System shall be used for nonmotorized mountain bike recreation, as described in the Decision Record.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: On the request of the State, the Secretary shall seek to acquire State land, or interests in State land, located within the Trail System by purchase from a willing seller or exchange.

paragraph.heading: Administration of acquired land.—
paragraph.content: Any land acquired under this subsection shall be administered as part of the Trail System.

subsection.heading: Fees.—
subsection.content: No fees shall be charged for access to, or use of, the Trail System and associated parking areas.

section.heading: Technical corrections to certain laws relating to Federal land in the State of Nevada

subsection.heading: Amendment to conveyance of Federal land in Storey County, Nevada.—
subsection.chapeau: Section 3009(d) of the Carl Levin and Howard P. “Buck” McKeon National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 (Public Law 113–291; 128 Stat. 3751) is amended—

paragraph.chapeau: in paragraph (1)—

subparagraph.content: by striking subparagraphs (B) through (D) and redesignating subparagraph (E) as subparagraph (D); and

by inserting after subparagraph (A) the following:“(B) Federal land.—The term ‘Federal land’ means the land generally depicted as ‘Federal land’ on the map.“(C) Map.—The term ‘map’ means the map entitled ‘Storey County Land Conveyance’ and dated June 6, 2018.”.

paragraph.chapeau: in paragraph (3)—

subparagraph.content: in subparagraph (A)(i), by striking “after completing the mining claim validity review under paragraph (2)(B), if requested by the County,”; and

subparagraph.chapeau: in subparagraph (B)—

clause.chapeau: in clause (i)—

subclause.content: in the matter preceding subclause (I), by striking “each parcel of land located in a mining townsite” and inserting “any Federal land”;
in subclause (I), by striking “mining townsite” and inserting “Federal land”; and
in subclause (II), by striking “mining townsite (including improvements to the mining townsite), as identified for conveyance on the map” and inserting “Federal land (including improvements)”;

clause.content: by striking clause (ii);

by striking the subparagraph designation and heading and all that follows through “With respect” in the matter preceding subclause (I) of clause (i) and inserting the following:“(B) Valid mining claims.—With respect”; and
by redesignating subclauses (I) and (II) as clauses (i) and (ii), respectively, and indenting appropriately;

paragraph.content: in paragraph (4)(A), by striking “a mining townsite conveyed under paragraph (3)(B)(i)(II)” and inserting “Federal land conveyed under paragraph (2)(B)(ii)”;
in paragraph (5), by striking “a mining townsite under paragraph (3)” and inserting “Federal land under paragraph (2)”;
in paragraph (6), in the matter preceding subparagraph (A), by striking “mining townsite” and inserting “Federal land”;

in paragraph (7), by striking “A mining townsite to be conveyed by the United States under paragraph (3)” and inserting “The exterior boundary of the Federal land to be conveyed by the United States under paragraph (2)”;

paragraph.chapeau: in paragraph (9)—

subparagraph.content: by striking “a mining townsite under paragraph (3)” and inserting “the Federal land under paragraph (2)”; and
by striking “the mining townsite” and inserting “the Federal land”;

paragraph.content: in paragraph (10), by striking “the examination” and all that follows through the period at the end and inserting “the conveyance under paragraph (2) should be completed by not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of the John D. Dingell, Jr. Conservation, Management, and Recreation Act.”;
by striking paragraphs (2) and (8);
by redesignating paragraphs (3) through (7) and (9) and (10) as paragraphs (2) through (6) and (7) and (8) respectively; and
by adding at the end the following:“(9) Availability of map.—The map shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management.”.

subsection.heading: Modification of utility corridor.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary shall realign the utility corridor established by section 301(a) of the Lincoln County Conservation, Recreation, and Development Act of 2004 (Public Law 108–424; 118 Stat. 2412) to be aligned as generally depicted on the map entitled “Proposed LCCRDA Utility Corridor Realignment” and dated March 14, 2017, by modifying the map entitled “Lincoln County Conservation, Recreation, and Development Act” (referred to in this subsection as the “Map”) and dated October 1, 2004, by—

paragraph.content: removing the utility corridor from sections 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 14, and 15, T. 7 N., R. 68 E., of the Map; and

paragraph.chapeau: redesignating the utility corridor so as to appear on the Map in—

subparagraph.content: sections 31, 32, and 33, T. 8 N., R. 68 E.;
sections 4, 5, 6, and 7, T. 7 N., R. 68 E.; and
sections 1 and 12, T. 7 N., 67 E.

subsection.heading: Final corrective patent in Clark County, Nevada.—

paragraph.heading: Validation of patent.—
paragraph.content: Patent number 27–2005–0081, issued by the Bureau of Land Management on February 18, 2005, is affirmed and validated as having been issued pursuant to, and in compliance with, the Nevada-Florida Land Exchange Authorization Act of 1988 (Public Law 100–275; 102 Stat. 52), the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.), and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.) for the benefit of the desert tortoise, other species, and the habitat of the desert tortoise and other species to increase the likelihood of the recovery of the desert tortoise and other species.

paragraph.heading: Ratification of reconfiguration.—
paragraph.content: The process used by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the Bureau of Land Management in reconfiguring the land described in paragraph (1), as depicted on Exhibit 1–4 of the Final Environmental Impact Statement for the Planned Development Project MSHCP, Lincoln County, NV (FWS–R8–ES–2008–N0136), and the reconfiguration provided for in special condition 10 of the Corps of Engineers Permit No. 000005042, are ratified.

subsection.heading: Issuance of corrective patent in Lincoln County, Nevada.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary, acting through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management, may issue a corrective patent for the 7,548 acres of land in Lincoln County, Nevada, depicted on the map prepared by the Bureau of Land Management entitled “Proposed Lincoln County Land Reconfiguration” and dated January 28, 2016.

paragraph.heading: Applicable law.—
paragraph.content: A corrective patent issued under paragraph (1) shall be treated as issued pursuant to, and in compliance with, the Nevada-Florida Land Exchange Authorization Act of 1988 (Public Law 100–275; 102 Stat. 52).

subsection.heading: Conveyance to Lincoln County, Nevada, to support a landfill.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, and subject to valid existing rights, at the request of Lincoln County, Nevada, the Secretary shall convey without consideration under the Act of June 14, 1926 (commonly known as the “Recreation and Public Purposes Act”) (44 Stat. 741, chapter 578; 43 U.S.C. 869 et seq.), to Lincoln County all right, title and interest of the United States in and to approximately 400 acres of land in Lincoln County, Nevada, more particularly described as follows: T. 11 S., R. 62, E., Section 25 E ½ of W ½; and W ½ of E ½; and E ½ of SE 1/4.

paragraph.heading: Reservation.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall reserve to the United States the mineral estate in any land conveyed under paragraph (1).

paragraph.heading: Use of conveyed land.—
paragraph.content: The land conveyed under paragraph (1) shall be used by Lincoln County, Nevada, to provide a suitable location for the establishment of a centralized landfill and to provide a designated area and authorized facilities to discourage unauthorized dumping and trash disposal on environmentally-sensitive public land. Lincoln County may not dispose of the land conveyed under paragraph (1).

paragraph.heading: Reversion.—
paragraph.chapeau: If Lincoln County, Nevada, ceases to use any parcel of land conveyed under paragraph (1) for the purposes described in paragraph (3)—

subparagraph.content: title to the parcel shall revert to the Secretary, at the option of the Secretary; and
Lincoln County shall be responsible for any reclamation necessary to restore the parcel to a condition acceptable to the Secretary.

subsection.heading: Mt. Moriah Wilderness, High Schells Wilderness, and Arc Dome Wilderness boundary adjustments.—

paragraph.heading: Amendments to the Pam White Wilderness Act of 2006.—
paragraph.content: Section 323 of the Pam White Wilderness Act of 2006 (16 U.S.C. 1132 note; 120 Stat. 3031) is amended by striking subsection (e) and inserting the following:“(e) Mt. Moriah Wilderness adjustment.—The boundary of the Mt. Moriah Wilderness established under section 2(13) of the Nevada Wilderness Protection Act of 1989 (16 U.S.C. 1132 note) is adjusted to include—“(1) the land identified as the ‘Mount Moriah Wilderness Area’ and ‘Mount Moriah Additions’ on the map entitled ‘Eastern White Pine County’ and dated November 29, 2006; and“(2) the land identified as ‘NFS Lands’ on the map entitled ‘Proposed Wilderness Boundary Adjustment Mt. Moriah Wilderness Area’ and dated January 19, 2017.“(f) High Schells Wilderness adjustment.—The boundary of the High Schells Wilderness established under subsection (a)(11) is adjusted—“(1) to include the land identified as ‘Include as Wilderness’ on the map entitled ‘McCoy Creek Adjustment’ and dated November 3, 2014; and“(2) to exclude the land identified as ‘NFS Lands’ on the map entitled ‘Proposed Wilderness Boundary Adjustment High Schells Wilderness Area’ and dated January 19, 2017.”.

paragraph.heading: Amendments to the Nevada Wilderness Protection Act of 1989.—
paragraph.content:
The Nevada Wilderness Protection Act of 1989 (Public Law 101–195; 16 U.S.C. 1132 note) is amended by adding at the end the following:
“Sec. 12. Arc Dome Boundary adjustmentThe boundary of the Arc Dome Wilderness established under section 2(2) is adjusted to exclude the land identified as ‘Exclude from Wilderness’ on the map entitled ‘Arc Dome Adjustment’ and dated November 3, 2014.”.

section.heading: Ashley Karst National Recreation and Geologic Area

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Management Plan.—
paragraph.content: The term “Management Plan” means the management plan for the Recreation Area prepared under subsection (e)(2)(A).

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “Map” means the map entitled “Northern Utah Lands Management Act-Overview” and dated February 4, 2019.

paragraph.heading: Recreation Area.—
paragraph.content: The term “Recreation Area” means the Ashley Karst National Recreation and Geologic Area established by subsection (b)(1).

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Agriculture.

paragraph.heading: State.—
paragraph.content: The term “State” means the State of Utah.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Subject to valid existing rights, there is established the Ashley Karst National Recreation and Geologic Area in the State.

paragraph.heading: Area included.—
paragraph.content: The Recreation Area shall consist of approximately 173,475 acres of land in the Ashley National Forest, as generally depicted on the Map.

subsection.heading: Purposes.—
subsection.content: The purposes of the Recreation Area are to conserve and protect the watershed, geological, recreational, wildlife, scenic, natural, cultural, and historic resources of the Recreation Area.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall prepare and submit to the Committee on Natural Resources and the Committee on Agriculture of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate a map and legal description of the Recreation Area.

paragraph.heading: Effect.—
paragraph.content: The map and legal description prepared under paragraph (1) shall have the same force and effect as if included in this section, except that the Secretary may correct minor errors in the map or legal description.

paragraph.heading: Availability.—
paragraph.content: A copy of the map and legal description prepared under paragraph (1) shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Forest Service.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall administer the Recreation Area in accordance with—

subparagraph.content: the laws generally applicable to the National Forest System, including the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 (16 U.S.C. 1600 et seq.);
this section; and
any other applicable law.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall prepare a management plan for the Recreation Area.

subparagraph.heading: Consultation.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall—

clause.content: prepare the management plan in consultation and coordination with Uintah County, Utah, and affected Indian Tribes; and
provide for public input in the preparation of the management plan.

subsection.heading: Uses.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary shall only allow such uses of the Recreation Area that would—

paragraph.content: further the purposes for which the Recreation Area is established; and
promote the long-term protection and management of the watershed and underground karst system of the Recreation Area.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Except as needed for emergency response or administrative purposes, the use of motorized vehicles in the Recreation Area shall be permitted only on roads and motorized routes designated in the Management Plan for the use of motorized vehicles.

paragraph.heading: New roads.—
paragraph.content: No new permanent or temporary roads or other motorized vehicle routes shall be constructed within the Recreation Area after the date of enactment of this Act.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Necessary maintenance or repairs to existing roads designated in the Management Plan for the use of motorized vehicles, including necessary repairs to keep existing roads free of debris or other safety hazards, shall be permitted after the date of enactment of this Act, consistent with the requirements of this section.

subparagraph.heading: Rerouting.—
subparagraph.content: Nothing in this subsection prevents the Secretary from rerouting an existing road or trail to protect Recreation Area resources from degradation, or to protect public safety, as determined to be appropriate by the Secretary.

subparagraph.heading: In General.—
subparagraph.content: Nothing in this section prohibits the use of snowmobiles and other over snow vehicles within the Recreation Area.

subparagraph.heading: Winter Recreation Use Plan.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall undertake a winter recreation use planning process, which shall include opportunities for use by snowmobiles or other over snow vehicles in appropriate areas of the Recreation Area.

paragraph.heading: Applicable law.—
paragraph.content: Activities authorized under this subsection shall be consistent with the applicable forest plan and travel management plan for, and any law (including regulations) applicable to, the Ashley National Forest.

paragraph.heading: Existing access.—
paragraph.content: The designation of the Recreation Area shall not affect the ability of authorized users to access, operate, and maintain water infrastructure facilities within the Recreation Area in accordance with applicable authorizations and permits.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall offer to enter into a cooperative agreement with authorized users and local governmental entities to provide, in accordance with any applicable law (including regulations)—

clause.content: access, including motorized access, for repair and maintenance to water infrastructure facilities within the Recreation Area, including Whiterocks Reservoir, subject to such terms and conditions as the Secretary determines to be necessary; and

access and maintenance by authorized users and local governmental entities for the continued delivery of water to the Ashley Valley if water flows cease or become diminished due to impairment of the karst system, subject to such terms and conditions as the Secretary determines to be necessary.

subsection.heading: Grazing.—
subsection.chapeau: The grazing of livestock in the Recreation Area, where established before the date of enactment of this Act, shall be allowed to continue, subject to such reasonable regulations, policies, and practices as the Secretary considers to be necessary in accordance with—

paragraph.content: applicable law (including regulations);
the purposes of the Recreation Area; and
the guidelines set forth in the report of the Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs of the House of Representatives accompanying H.R. 5487 of the 96th Congress (H. Rept. 96–617).

subsection.heading: Fish and wildlife.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section affects the jurisdiction of the State with respect to the management of fish and wildlife on Federal land in the State.

subsection.heading: Wildlife water projects.—
subsection.content: The Secretary, in consultation with the State, may authorize wildlife water projects (including guzzlers) within the Recreation Area.

subsection.heading: Water rights.—
subsection.chapeau: Nothing in this section—

paragraph.content: constitutes an express or implied reservation by the United States of any water rights with respect to the Recreation Area;
affects any water rights in the State;
affects the use or allocation, in existence on the date of enactment of this Act, of any water, water right, or interest in water;
affects any vested absolute or decreed conditional water right in existence on the date of enactment of this Act, including any water right held by the United States;
affects any interstate water compact in existence on the date of enactment of this Act; or
shall be considered to be a relinquishment or reduction of any water rights reserved or appropriated by the United States in the State on or before the date of enactment of this Act.

subsection.heading: Withdrawal.—
subsection.chapeau: Subject to valid existing rights, all Federal land in the Recreation Area is withdrawn from—

paragraph.content: all forms of entry, appropriation, and disposal under the public land laws;
location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and
operation of the mineral leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal leasing laws.

subsection.heading: Vegetation management.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section prevents the Secretary from conducting vegetation management projects, including fuels reduction activities, within the Recreation Area for the purposes of improving water quality and reducing risks from wildfire.

subsection.heading: Wildland fire operations.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section prohibits the Secretary, in consultation with other Federal, State, local, and Tribal agencies, as appropriate, from conducting wildland fire treatment operations or restoration operations in the Recreation Area, consistent with the purposes of this section.

subsection.heading: Recreation fees.—
subsection.content: Except for fees for improved campgrounds, the Secretary is prohibited from collecting recreation entrance or recreation use fees within the Recreation Area.

subsection.heading: Communication infrastructure.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section affects the continued use of, and access to, communication infrastructure (including necessary upgrades) within the Recreation Area, in accordance with applicable authorizations and permits.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section affects non-Federal land or interests in non-Federal land within the Recreation Area.

paragraph.heading: Access.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall provide reasonable access to non-Federal land or interests in non-Federal land within the Recreation Area.

subsection.heading: Outfitting and guide activities.—
subsection.content: Outfitting and guide services within the Recreation Area, including commercial outfitting and guide services, are authorized in accordance with this section and other applicable law (including regulations).

section.heading: John Wesley Powell National Conservation Area

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Map.—
paragraph.content: The term “Map” means the Bureau of Land Management map entitled “Proposed John Wesley Powell National Conservation Area” and dated December 10, 2018.

paragraph.heading: National Conservation Area.—
paragraph.content: The term “National Conservation Area” means the John Wesley Powell National Conservation Area established by subsection (b)(1).

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Subject to valid existing rights, there is established the John Wesley Powell National Conservation Area in the State of Utah.

paragraph.heading: Area included.—
paragraph.content: The National Conservation Area shall consist of approximately 29,868 acres of public land administered by the Bureau of Land Management as generally depicted on the Map.

subsection.heading: Purposes.—
subsection.content: The purposes of the National Conservation Area are to conserve, protect, and enhance for the benefit of present and future generations the nationally significant historic, cultural, natural, scientific, scenic, recreational, archaeological, educational, and wildlife resources of the National Conservation Area.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall prepare and file a map and legal description of the National Conservation Area with the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate and the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives.

paragraph.heading: Effect.—
paragraph.content: The map and legal description prepared under paragraph (1) shall have the same force and effect as if included in this section, except that the Secretary may correct minor errors in the map or legal description.

paragraph.heading: Availability.—
paragraph.content: A copy of the map and legal description shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management.

subsection.heading: Management.—
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary shall manage the National Conservation Area—

paragraph.content: in a manner that conserves, protects, and enhances the resources of the National Conservation Area;

paragraph.chapeau: in accordance with—

subparagraph.content: the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.);
this section; and
any other applicable law; and

paragraph.content: as a component of the National Landscape Conservation System.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall develop a management plan for the National Conservation Area.

subparagraph.heading: Consultation.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall prepare the management plan—

clause.content: in consultation and coordination with the State of Utah, Uintah County, and affected Indian Tribes; and
after providing for public input.

subsection.heading: Uses.—
subsection.content: The Secretary shall only allow such uses of the National Conservation Area as the Secretary determines would further the purposes for which the National Conservation is established.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary may acquire land or interests in land within the boundaries of the National Conservation Area by purchase from a willing seller, donation, or exchange.

paragraph.heading: Incorporation in national conservation area.—
paragraph.content: Any land or interest in land located inside the boundary of the National Conservation Area that is acquired by the United States after the date of enactment of this Act shall be added to and administered as part of the National Conservation Area.

paragraph.heading: State land.—
paragraph.content: On request of the Utah School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration and, if practicable, not later than 5 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall seek to acquire all State-owned land within the boundaries of the National Conservation Area by exchange or purchase, subject to the appropriation of necessary funds.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Subject to paragraph (2), except in cases in which motorized vehicles are needed for administrative purposes or to respond to an emergency, the use of motorized vehicles in the National Conservation Area shall be permitted only on roads designated in the management plan.

paragraph.heading: Use of motorized vehicles prior to completion of management plan.—
paragraph.content: Prior to completion of the management plan, the use of motorized vehicles within the National Conservation Area shall be permitted in accordance with the applicable Bureau of Land Management resource management plan.

subsection.heading: Grazing.—
subsection.chapeau: The grazing of livestock in the National Conservation Area, where established before the date of enactment of this Act, shall be allowed to continue, subject to such reasonable regulations, policies, and practices as the Secretary considers to be necessary in accordance with—

paragraph.content: applicable law (including regulations);
the purposes of the National Conservation Area; and

the guidelines set forth in Appendix A of the report of the Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs of the House of Representatives accompanying H.R. 2570 of the 101st Congress (House Report 101–405).

subsection.heading: Fish and wildlife.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section affects the jurisdiction of the State of Utah with respect to the management of fish and wildlife on Federal land in the State.

subsection.heading: Wildlife water projects.—
subsection.content: The Secretary, in consultation with the State of Utah, may authorize wildlife water projects (including guzzlers) within the National Conservation Area.

subsection.heading: Greater sage-grouse conservation projects.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section affects the authority of the Secretary to undertake Greater sage-grouse (Centrocercus urophasianus) conservation projects to maintain and improve Greater sage-grouse habitat, including the management of vegetation through mechanical means, to further the purposes of the National Conservation Area.

subsection.heading: Water rights.—
subsection.chapeau: Nothing in this section—

paragraph.content: constitutes an express or implied reservation by the United States of any water rights with respect to the National Conservation Area;
affects any water rights in the State;
affects the use or allocation, in existence on the date of enactment of this Act, of any water, water right, or interest in water;
affects any vested absolute or decreed conditional water right in existence on the date of enactment of this Act, including any water right held by the United States;
affects any interstate water compact in existence on the date of enactment of this Act; or
shall be considered to be a relinquishment or reduction of any water rights reserved or appropriated by the United States in the State on or before the date of enactment of this Act.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section creates a protective perimeter or buffer zone around the National Conservation Area.

paragraph.heading: Activities outside National Conservation Area.—
paragraph.content: The fact that an authorized activity or use on land outside the National Conservation Area can be seen or heard within the National Conservation Area shall not preclude the activity or use outside the boundary of the Area.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: Subject to valid existing rights, all Federal land in the National Conservation Area (including any land acquired after the date of enactment of this Act) is withdrawn from—

subparagraph.content: all forms of entry, appropriation, and disposal under the public land laws;
location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and
operation of the mineral leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal leasing laws.

subsection.heading: Vegetation management.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section prevents the Secretary from conducting vegetation management projects, including fuels reduction activities, within the National Conservation Area that are consistent with this section and that further the purposes of the National Conservation Area.

subsection.heading: Wildland fire operations.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section prohibits the Secretary, in consultation with other Federal, State, local, and Tribal agencies, as appropriate, from conducting wildland fire prevention and restoration operations in the National Conservation Area, consistent with the purposes of this section.

subsection.heading: Recreation fees.—
subsection.content: Except for improved campgrounds, the Secretary is prohibited from collecting recreation entrance or use fees within the National Conservation Area.

subsection.heading: Outfitting and guide activities.—
subsection.content: Outfitting and guide services within the National Conservation Area, including commercial outfitting and guide services, are authorized in accordance with this section and other applicable law (including regulations).

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section affects non-Federal land or interests in non-Federal land within the National Conservation Area.

paragraph.heading: Reasonable access.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall provide reasonable access to non-Federal land or interests in non-Federal land within the National Conservation Area.

subsection.heading: Research and interpretive management.—
subsection.content: The Secretary may establish programs and projects for the conduct of scientific, historical, cultural, archeological, and natural studies through the use of public and private partnerships that further the purposes of the National Conservation Area.

section.heading: Alaska Native Vietnam era veterans land allotment

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The term “available Federal land” means Federal land in the State that—

clause.content: is vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved and is identified as available for selection under subsection (b)(5); or

clause.chapeau: has been selected by, but not yet conveyed to—

subclause.content: the State, if the State agrees to voluntarily relinquish the selection of the Federal land for selection by an eligible individual; or

a Regional Corporation or a Village Corporation, if the Regional Corporation or Village Corporation agrees to voluntarily relinquish the selection of the Federal land for selection by an eligible individual.

subparagraph.heading: Exclusions.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The term “available Federal land” does not include any Federal land in the State that is—

subclause.content: a right-of-way of the TransAlaska Pipeline; or
an inner or outer corridor of such a right-of-way;

clause.content: withdrawn or acquired for purposes of the Armed Forces;
under review for a pending right-of-way for a natural gas corridor;
within the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge;
within a unit of the National Forest System;
designated as wilderness by Congress;
within a unit of the National Park System, a National Preserve, or a National Monument;
within a component of the National Trails System;
within a component of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System; or
within the National Petroleum Reserve–Alaska.

paragraph.heading: Eligible individual.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “eligible individual” means an individual who, as determined by the Secretary in accordance with subsection (c)(1), is—

subparagraph.chapeau: a Native veteran—

clause.content: who served in the Armed Forces during the period between August 5, 1964, and December 31, 1971; and

clause.chapeau: has not received an allotment made pursuant to—

subclause.content: the Act of May 17, 1906 (34 Stat. 197, chapter 2469) (as in effect on December 17, 1971);
section 14(h)(5) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (43 U.S.C. 1613(h)(5)); or
section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (43 U.S.C. 1629g); or

subparagraph.content: is the personal representative of the estate of a deceased eligible individual described in subparagraph (A), who has been duly appointed in the appropriate Alaska State court or a registrar has qualified, acting for the benefit of the heirs of the estate of a deceased eligible individual described in subparagraph (A).

paragraph.heading: Native; regional corporation; village corporation.—
paragraph.content: The terms “Native”, “Regional Corporation”, and “Village Corporation” have the meanings given those terms in section 3 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (43 U.S.C. 1602).

paragraph.heading: State.—
paragraph.content: The term “State” means the State of Alaska.

paragraph.heading: Veteran.—
paragraph.content: The term “veteran” has the meaning given the term in section 101 of title 38, United States Code.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, shall provide to the Secretary a list of all members of the Armed Forces who served during the period between August 5, 1964, and December 31, 1971.

subparagraph.heading: Use.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary shall use the information provided under subparagraph (A) to determine whether an individual meets the military service requirements under subsection (a)(2)(A)(i).

subparagraph.heading: Outreach and assistance.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, shall conduct outreach, and provide assistance in applying for allotments, to eligible individuals.

paragraph.heading: Regulations.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this section, the Secretary shall promulgate regulations to carry out this subsection.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: An eligible individual—

clause.content: may select 1 parcel of not less than 2.5 acres and not more than 160 acres of available Federal land; and
on making a selection pursuant to clause (i), shall submit to the Secretary an allotment selection application for the applicable parcel of available Federal land.

subparagraph.heading: Selection period.—
subparagraph.content: An eligible individual may apply for an allotment during the 5-year period beginning on the effective date of the final regulations issued under paragraph (2).

paragraph.heading: Conflicting selections.—
paragraph.chapeau: If 2 or more eligible individuals submit to the Secretary an allotment selection application under paragraph (3)(A)(ii) for the same parcel of available Federal land, the Secretary shall—

subparagraph.content: give preference to the selection application received on the earliest date; and
provide to each eligible individual the selection application of whom is rejected under subparagraph (A) an opportunity to select a substitute parcel of available Federal land.

paragraph.heading: Identification of available federal land administered by the bureau of land management.—

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the State, Regional Corporations, and Village Corporations, shall identify Federal land administered by the Bureau of Land Management as available Federal land for allotment selection in the State by eligible individuals.

subparagraph.heading: Certification; survey.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall—

clause.content: certify that the available Federal land identified under subparagraph (A) is free of known contamination; and
survey the available Federal land identified under subparagraph (A) into aliquot parts and lots, segregating all navigable and meanderable waters and land not available for allotment selection.

subparagraph.heading: Maps.—
subparagraph.content: As soon as practicable after the date on which available Federal land is identified under subparagraph (A), the Secretary shall submit to Congress, and publish in the Federal Register, 1 or more maps depicting the identified available Federal land.

subparagraph.heading: Conveyances.—
subparagraph.chapeau: Any available Federal land conveyed to an eligible individual under this paragraph shall be subject to—

clause.content: valid existing rights; and
the reservation of minerals to the United States.

subparagraph.heading: Intent of congress.—
subparagraph.content: It is the intent of Congress that not later than 1 year after the date on which an eligible individual submits an allotment selection application for available Federal land that meets the requirements of this section, as determined by the Secretary, the Secretary shall issue to the eligible individual a certificate of allotment with respect to the available Federal land covered by the allotment selection application, subject to the requirements of subparagraph (D).

subsection.heading: Identification of available federal land in units of the national wildlife refuge system.—

paragraph.heading: Report.—
paragraph.chapeau: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall—

subparagraph.content: conduct a study to determine whether any additional Federal lands within units of the National Wildlife Refuge System in the State should be made available for allotment selection; and
report the findings and conclusions of the study to Congress.

paragraph.heading: Content of the report.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall include in the report required under paragraph (1)—

subparagraph.content: the Secretary’s determination whether Federal lands within units of the National Wildlife Refuge System in the State should be made available for allotment selection by eligible individuals; and

identification of the specific areas (including maps) within units of the National Wildlife Refuge System in the State that the Secretary determines should be made available, consistent with the mission of the National Wildlife Refuge System and the specific purposes for which the unit was established, and this subsection.

paragraph.heading: Factors to be considered.—
paragraph.chapeau: In determining whether Federal lands within units of the National Wildlife Refuge System in the State should be made available under paragraph (1)(A), the Secretary shall take into account—

subparagraph.content: the proximity of the Federal land made available for allotment selection under subsection (b)(5) to eligible individuals;
the proximity of the units of the National Wildlife Refuge System in the State to eligible individuals; and

the amount of additional Federal land within units of the National Wildlife Refuge System in the State that the Secretary estimates would be necessary to make allotments available for selection by eligible individuals.

paragraph.heading: Identifying federal land in units of the national wildlife refuge system.—
paragraph.chapeau: In identifying whether Federal lands within units of the National Wildlife Refuge System in the State should be made available for allotment under paragraph (2)(B), the Secretary shall not identify any Federal land in a unit of the National Wildlife Refuge System—

subparagraph.chapeau: the conveyance of which, independently or as part of a group of allotments—

clause.content: could significantly interfere with biological, physical, cultural, scenic, recreational, natural quiet, or subsistence values of the unit of the National Wildlife Refuge System;
could obstruct access by the public or the Fish and Wildlife Service to the resource values of the unit;
could trigger development or future uses in an area that would adversely affect resource values of the surrounding National Wildlife Refuge System land;
could open an area of a unit to new access and uses that adversely affect resources values of the unit; or
could interfere with the management plan of the unit;

subparagraph.content: that is located within 300 feet from the shore of a navigable water body;
that is not consistent with the purposes for which the unit of the National Wildlife Refuge System was established;
that is designated as wilderness by Congress; or
that is within the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

subsection.heading: Limitation.—
subsection.content: No Federal land may be identified for selection or made available for allotment within a unit of the National Wildlife Refuge System unless it has been authorized by an Act of Congress subsequent to the date of enactment of this Act. Further, any proposed conveyance of land within a unit of the National Wildlife Refuge System must have been identified by the Secretary in accordance with subsection (c)(4) in the report to Congress required by subsection (c) and include patent provisions that the land remains subject to the laws and regulations governing the use and development of the Refuge.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The term “affected area” means land along the approximately 116-mile stretch of the Red River, from its confluence with the north fork of the Red River on the west to the 98th meridian on the east.

subparagraph.heading: Exclusions.—
subparagraph.content: The term “affected area” does not include the portion of the Red River within the boundary depicted on the survey prepared by the Bureau of Land Management entitled “Township 5 South, Range 14 West, of the Indian Meridian, Oklahoma, Dependent Resurvey and Survey” and dated February 28, 2006.

paragraph.heading: Gradient boundary survey method.—
paragraph.content: The term “gradient boundary survey method” means the measurement technique used to locate the South Bank boundary line in accordance with the methodology established in Oklahoma v. Texas, 261 U.S. 340 (1923) (recognizing that the boundary line along the Red River is subject to change due to erosion and accretion).

paragraph.heading: Landowner.—
paragraph.content: The term “landowner” means any individual, group, association, corporation, federally recognized Indian tribe or member of such an Indian tribe, or other private or governmental legal entity that owns an interest in land in the affected area.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary, acting through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management.

paragraph.heading: South bank.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “South Bank” means the water-washed and relatively permanent elevation or acclivity (commonly known as a “cut bank”) along the southerly or right side of the Red River that—

subparagraph.content: separates the bed of that river from the adjacent upland, whether valley or hill; and

subparagraph.chapeau: usually serves, as specified in the fifth paragraph of Oklahoma v. Texas, 261 U.S. 340 (1923)—

clause.content: to confine the waters within the bed; and
to preserve the course of the river.

paragraph.heading: South bank boundary line.—
paragraph.content: The term “South Bank boundary line” means the boundary, with respect to title and ownership, between the States of Oklahoma and Texas identified through the gradient boundary survey method that does not impact or alter the permanent political boundary line between the States along the Red River, as outlined under article II, section B of the Red River Boundary Compact enacted by the States and consented to by Congress pursuant to Public Law 106–288 (114 Stat. 919).

subsection.heading: Survey of south bank boundary line.—

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Secretary shall commission a survey to identify the South Bank boundary line in the affected area.

subparagraph.heading: Requirements.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The survey shall—

clause.content: adhere to the gradient boundary survey method;
span the length of the affected area;

clause.chapeau: be conducted by 1 or more independent third-party surveyors that are—

subclause.content: licensed and qualified to conduct official gradient boundary surveys; and

subclause.chapeau: selected by the Secretary, in consultation with—

item.content: the Texas General Land Office;
the Oklahoma Commissioners of the Land Office, in consultation with the attorney general of the State of Oklahoma; and
each affected federally recognized Indian Tribe; and

clause.content: subject to the availability of appropriations, be completed not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: Not later than 60 days after the date on which the survey or a portion of the survey under paragraph (1)(A) is completed, the Secretary shall submit the survey for approval to—

clause.content: the Texas General Land Office;
the Oklahoma Commissioners of the Land Office, in consultation with the attorney general of the State of Oklahoma; and
each affected federally recognized Indian Tribe.

subparagraph.heading: Timing of approval.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 60 days after the date on which each of the Texas General Land Office, the Oklahoma Commissioners of the Land Office, in consultation with the attorney general of the State of Oklahoma, and each affected federally recognized Indian Tribe notify the Secretary of the approval of the boundary survey or a portion of the survey by the applicable office or federally recognized Indian Tribe, the Secretary shall determine whether to approve the survey or portion of the survey, subject to subparagraph (D).

subparagraph.heading: Submission of portions of survey for approval.—
subparagraph.content: As portions of the survey are completed, the Secretary may submit the completed portions of the survey for approval under subparagraph (A).

subparagraph.heading: Written approval.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall only approve the survey, or a portion of the survey, that has the written approval of each of—

clause.content: the Texas General Land Office;
the Oklahoma Commissioners of the Land Office, in consultation with the attorney general of the State of Oklahoma; and
each affected federally recognized Indian Tribe.

subsection.heading: Survey of individual parcels.—
subsection.content: Surveys of individual parcels in the affected area shall be conducted in accordance with the boundary survey approved under subsection (b)(2).

subsection.heading: Notice and availability of survey.—
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 60 days after the date on which the boundary survey is approved under subsection (b)(2), the Secretary shall—

paragraph.chapeau: publish notice of the approval of the survey in—

subparagraph.content: the Federal Register; and
1 or more local newspapers; and

paragraph.chapeau: on request, furnish to any landowner a copy of—

subparagraph.content: the survey; and

subparagraph.chapeau: any field notes relating to—

clause.content: the individual parcel of the landowner; or
any individual parcel adjacent to the individual parcel of the landowner.

subsection.heading: Effect of section.—
subsection.chapeau: Nothing in this section—

paragraph.content: modifies any interest of the State of Oklahoma or Texas, or the sovereignty, property, or trust rights of any federally recognized Indian Tribe, relating to land located north of the South Bank boundary line, as established by the survey;
modifies any land patented under the Act of December 22, 1928 (45 Stat. 1069, chapter 47; 43 U.S.C. 1068) (commonly known as the “Color of Title Act”), before the date of enactment of this Act;
modifies or supersedes the Red River Boundary Compact enacted by the States of Oklahoma and Texas and consented to by Congress pursuant to Public Law 106–288 (114 Stat. 919);
creates or reinstates any Indian reservation or any portion of such a reservation;
modifies any interest or any property or trust rights of any individual Indian allottee; or

alters any valid right of the State of Oklahoma or the Kiowa, Comanche, or Apache Indian tribes to the mineral interest trust fund established under the Act of June 12, 1926 (44 Stat. 740, chapter 572).

subsection.heading: Authorization of appropriations.—
subsection.content: There is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary to carry out this section $1,000,000.

subsection.heading: Exchange of coal preference right lease applications.—

paragraph.heading: Definition of bidding right.—
paragraph.chapeau: In this subsection, the term “bidding right” means an appropriate legal instrument or other written documentation, including an entry in an account managed by the Secretary, issued or created under subpart 3435 of title 43, Code of Federal Regulations, that may be used—

subparagraph.content: in lieu of a monetary payment for 50 percent of a bonus bid for a coal lease sale under the Mineral Leasing Act (30 U.S.C. 181 et seq.); or
as a monetary credit against 50 percent of any rental or royalty payments due under any Federal coal lease.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: If the Secretary retires a coal preference right lease application under the Mineral Leasing Act (30 U.S.C. 181 et seq.) by issuing a bidding right in exchange for the relinquishment of the coal preference right lease application, the bidding right subsequently may be used in lieu of 50 percent of the amount owed for any monetary payment of—

clause.content: a bonus in a coal lease sale; or
rental or royalty under a Federal coal lease.

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.content: The Secretary shall calculate a payment of amounts owed to a relevant State under section 35(a) of the Mineral Leasing Act (30 U.S.C. 191(a)) based on the combined value of the bidding rights and amounts received.

clause.heading: Amounts received.—
clause.content: Except as provided in this paragraph, for purposes of calculating the payment of amounts owed to a relevant State under clause (i) only, a bidding right shall be considered amounts received.

subparagraph.heading: Requirement.—
subparagraph.content: The total number of bidding rights issued by the Secretary under subparagraph (A) before October 1, 2029, shall not exceed the number of bidding rights that reflect a value equivalent to $67,000,000.

paragraph.heading: Source of payments.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall make payments to the relevant State under paragraph (2) from monetary payments received by the Secretary when bidding rights are exercised under this section.

paragraph.heading: Treatment of payments.—
paragraph.content: A payment to a State under this subsection shall be treated as a payment under section 35(a) of the Mineral Leasing Act (30 U.S.C. 191(a)).

subparagraph.heading: Transferability.—
subparagraph.content: A bidding right issued for a coal preference right lease application under the Mineral Leasing Act (30 U.S.C. 181 et seq.) shall be fully transferable to any other person.
